summarize this our Ways to Invest
Clearly, neither of these two dimensions of corporate in-
vesting ‚Äì strategic versus financial and tightly linked
versus loosely linked ‚Äì is an either-or proposition. Most
investments will fall somewhere along a spectrum be-
tween the two poles of each pair of attributes. Still, over-
laying the two dimensions creates a useful framework
to help a company assess its current and potential VC in-
vestments. (See the exhibit ‚ÄúMapping Your Corporate VC
Investments‚Äù for a depiction of these distinct types of cor-
porate venture capital.)
Driving Investments. This type of investment is char-
acterized by a strategic rationale and tight links between
a start-up and the operations of the investing company.
For instance, Agilent Technologies created a VC operation
to invest in three strategic areas ‚Äì life sciences, wireless
communications, and optical communications ‚Äì that it
has identified as key to its growth. The VC arm works
closely with the company‚Äôs existing businesses to share
information, qualify investment opportunities, and con-
nect portfolio companies to Agilent‚Äôs own initiatives. For
example, Agilent has recently invested in a start-up com-
pany making wireless radio-frequency devices, a product
area Agilent plans to explore in its own business. If this
investment is successful, Agilent‚Äôs future business will
benefit; if it fails, Agilent will get a valuable early warning
about pitfalls to avoid in that business.
Similarly, Microsoft has earmarked more than $1 bil-
lion to invest in start-up companies that could help ad-
vance its new Internet services architecture, ‚Äú.Net.‚Äù This
Microsoft technology ‚Äì which will enable its Windows
platform to provide a variety of Internet services ‚Äì is a
contender to set the standards for the next generation of
products and services over the Web. Microsoft is funding
start-up firms that will exploit its architecture and, in so
doing, promote the adoption of the Microsoft standard
over rival approaches from Sun Microsystems and IBM.
The start-ups are tightly linked to Microsoft‚Äôs operations
through the Windows software and tools that the com-
pany provides to them for the development of their own
products.
The strategic value of Microsoft‚Äôs .Net investments is
highlighted by the company‚Äôs decision to make them in
the shadow of earlier VC investment losses. The company
has written off staggering sums ‚Äì $980million in the third
quarter of 2000 alone ‚Äì in its corporate VC portfolio. But
rather than backing off, Microsoft is charging ahead with
new .Net investments. Because they could help the com-
pany win the battle over the next Internet services stan-
dard ‚Äì a major strategic victory ‚Äì it is willing to risk sub-
stantial financial losses.
Although it‚Äôs clear that many driving investments can
advance a corporate strategy, there are limits to what they
can achieve. The tight coupling of these investments with
a company‚Äôs current processes means that these invest-
ments will sustain the current strategy. They will be un-
likely to help a corporation cope with disruptive strategies
or to identify new opportunities when the company must
go beyond its current capabilities to respond to a change
in the environment. If a corporation wants to transcend
current strategy and processes, it should not rely on driv-
ing investments, which are ill suited for these tasks.
Enabling Investments. In this mode of VC investing,
a company still makes investments primarily for strategic
reasons but does not couple the venture tightly with its
own operations. The theory is that a successful invest-
6 harvard business review
M a k i n g S e n s e o f Co r p o rat e Ve n t u re Ca p i ta l
While corporate VC investments have generated decidedly
uneven financial returns, they should not be judged primarily
on that basis. They should be thought of as important ways for
a company to fuel the growth of its business.
ment will enable a company‚Äôs own businesses to benefit
but that a strong operational link between the start-up
and the company isn‚Äôt necessary to realize that benefit.
This may seem too good to be true. How can a company‚Äôs
strategy benefit if its operations are not tightly linked
to the venture? One answer lies in the notion of comple-
mentarity: Having one product makes a person want
another. A company can take advantage of this notion by
using its VC investments to stimulate the development of
the ecosystem in which it operates ‚Äì that is, the suppliers,
customers, and third-party developers that make goods
and services that stimulate demand for the company‚Äôs
own offerings.
Intel Capital, the investment arm of the semiconductor
giant, is a paradigmatic example of a company making
enabling investments. Back in the early 1990s, long before
corporate venture capital was fashionable, Intel realized
it could benefit from nurturing start-ups making com-
plementary products: Demand for them could spur in-
creased demand for Intel‚Äôs own microprocessor products.
So Intel invested in hundreds of companies whose prod-
ucts ‚Äì such as video, audio, and graphics hardware and
software ‚Äì required increasingly powerful microproces-
sors inside the computers they ran on, thereby stimulat-
ing sales of Intel Pentium chips. Whereas Microsoft‚Äôs
VC investments in start-ups seek to establish a new stan-
dard, in Intel‚Äôs case, the investments have mainly been
aimed at increasing its revenue by boosting sales within
the current Wintel operating system standard.

Here is information about software that I have built. Summarise for me what you know about my software.
I want to build a SaaS for owner-builders. The SaaS will be used in countries such as Australian, USA, Canada, UK and the like.

The target market is owner-builders in the city. They are curious and are interested to self-help. The persona is a couple who want to build their dream home. They are looking for guidance for them to project manage their build.

One feature of the software is a Task List. It helps the owner-builder and the trades manage the construction project timeline. The owner-builder can allocate tasks and schedule work for the trades. Another feature is collaboration and communication feature. It is similar to the first feature. But it allows for document sharing. The Owner-builder will be able to provide the same documents to all stakeholders. A further feature is an integration with the user's favourite email (Gmail, Outlook etc) so that the owner builder will be able to track all communication for the project. The owner-builder will be able to manage all of their project files and manage compliance requirements. A record keeping feature for document management with secure cloud storage. Another feature is templates and workflows to assist the owner-builder manage their project. This includes contracts, change orders / variations, and other documents needed to manage the trades. These are the main features that I have built for now.

Question: What specific pain points or challenges do owner-builders face that your software aims to address?
Answer: Owner builders generally do not know their legal obligations, they have no experience with construction project management, and they are looking for a system that can help them manage their project.

Question: Are there any unique or innovative features that set your software apart from competitors in the market?
Answer: The software is built for owner builders. It offers contracts and workflows that only builders need to manage their jobs and their compliance obligations. Other construction software focuses on builders and contractors.

Question: How does your software simplify or streamline the construction project management process for owner-builders?
Answer: Owners can document all their files and emails in automated system per topic. Owners can manage trades. Owners can use the system workflows to project manage their job.

Question: Are there any specific integrations or partnerships with other software or tools that enhance the functionality of your SaaS?
Answer: The software is integrated with Gmail and Outlook so that all communication can be automatically saved into appropriate topics and by trade.

Question: Does your software cater to a particular type of construction project or can it be adapted for various project sizes and complexities?
Answer: The software targets only owner builders. These people are not licenced builders nor trades people. These people are building their dream home for them to live in with their family.

Question: What level of support and resources do you provide to help users make the most of your software (e.g., customer support, tutorials, community forums, etc.)?
Answer: We provide videos on why they should carry out certain tasks. To provide tutorials on how to use the software and the software is easy to use. We provide an online community forum for owner builders.

Question: Is your software designed for both beginners and experienced owner-builders, or does it target a specific skill level?
Answer: The software is built for beginners and experienced owner builders.

Question: How does your pricing structure accommodate different user needs and budgets? Are there any additional features or services available for higher-tier plans?
Answer: We have not thought too much about pricing tiers yet. But if would be ideal for us to charge $100 per month and require people to pay annually. I will have you help me further with this study at a later time.

Question: Can your software be customized to suit the specific needs of an owner-builder, such as unique workflows or reporting requirements?
Answer: Yes the software can be customised for the owner builders needs. With the software has many features which allows us to manage user access.

Question: How does your software ensure the security and privacy of user data, particularly with regards to sensitive financial information and document storage?
Answer: The software uses AWS security systems. We have adopted best practises from AWS. The software uses state-of-the-art serverless technology.

Question: Are there any specific milestones or checkpoints built into the software that help owner-builders track their progress throughout the construction process?
Answer: No

Question: Does the software provide any budgeting tools or features to help owner-builders manage their construction costs more effectively?
Answer: No

Question: Can the software assist with sourcing and evaluating contractors, subcontractors, or suppliers for the project?
Answer: No

Question: Are there any collaboration features within the software that facilitate communication and coordination between the owner-builder and the various trades involved in the project?
Answer: No

Question: How does the software handle change orders or variations, and does it have built-in features to manage the approval process for these changes?
Answer: No

Question: Can the software generate reports or summaries to help owner-builders monitor the overall progress, budget, and timeline of their project?
Answer: No

Question: Are there any mobile apps or responsive designs available to allow owner-builders to access and manage their project on the go?
Answer: The web application is mobile responsive. All the features available on the desktop are also available on the mobile through Google Chrome.

Question: Does the software offer any pre-built templates for common construction project management tasks or documents, such as contracts, permits, and inspections?
Answer: A software offers pre-built contract to engage trades in the compliant manner. There's also a suite of contract notices like delay notices and variation directions.

Question: Can the software help owner-builders identify and stay on top of their compliance obligations, such as insurance, permits, and building codes?
Answer: Yes the software does help I understand top of their compliance obligations.

Question: Are there any training resources or onboarding programs available to help owner-builders get started with the software and maximize its benefits?
Answer: Yes there are onboarding videos to help the users get started and understand why they need to carry out these tasks.

Question: How does the software assist owner-builders in managing project timelines and schedules, including setting deadlines and monitoring the progress of each task?
Answer: There is a task list feature. Owners can allocate tasks with due dates. The tasks can be closed off once completed. The tasks can be allocated to the trade communication.

Question: Are there any features within the software that can help owner-builders identify and address potential risks or issues that may arise during the construction process?
Answer: Yes, the contract can help the owners manage risks. The email and communication management module also helps manage risks. The workflows and templates help further manage risks.

Question: Can the software facilitate the process of obtaining and managing permits, inspections, and other regulatory requirements?
Answer: No

Question: Does the software offer any tools or resources to help owner-builders plan and organize the overall design and layout of their dream home?
Answer: The software provides a platform for collaboration. Owners can invite their trades as well as their designers into the system so that they can document their communication. There's also an email integration so that all our communication is saved into one file per trade.

Question: Are there any notification or reminder features in the software to help owner-builders stay on top of important tasks, deadlines, and compliance requirements?
Answer: The task list has a due date function. The system emails people when the due date is reached.

Why you should use MakeMyAffidavit.com software and the real-life problems MMA solves.

Why Use the Software:

Efficient and cost-effective: MakeMyAffidavit helps litigants and legal professionals streamline their client intake process, organize case files, and create affidavits with ease. This results in a more efficient workflow and significant cost savings.

Improved communication: The software enables enhanced collaboration between litigants, legal professionals, and their trusted network of family, friends, and service providers. This ensures that everyone stays informed and on the same page, reducing the risk of miscommunication.

Intelligent guidance: MakeMyAffidavit uses artificial intelligence to guide users through the process of creating their legal story. It asks relevant questions based on their specific legal issue, helping them provide a comprehensive and coherent narrative that is easily understood by legal professionals.

Document organization: The software automatically organizes and labels documents, making it easy for users to locate and reference the information they need when they need it.

Security and privacy: MakeMyAffidavit is built on state-of-the-art technology and employs best practices in security and privacy, ensuring that users' sensitive data is protected.

Real-Life Problems Solved:

Limited funds and affordability: MakeMyAffidavit allows litigants with limited funds or those involved in disputes with a low monetary value to efficiently manage their legal matters without incurring excessive legal costs.

Inexperience with legal processes: The software guides users through the process of creating their legal story and helps them understand the structure and format required for affidavits and other legal documents.

Difficulty providing information to legal professionals: MakeMyAffidavit's AI-powered questioning and document organization features make it easier for litigants to provide clear, concise, and comprehensive information to their lawyers.

Inefficient file organization and document management: The software simplifies document organization and management, ensuring that users can easily access and reference their files when needed.

By addressing these real-life problems and providing the benefits mentioned, MakeMyAffidavit positions itself as a valuable tool for litigants and legal professionals alike. Its unique combination of features, ease of use, and cost-effectiveness makes it a compelling choice for those seeking to improve their legal processes and outcomes.

And on the high intent end of the spectrum, we've got painkiller products. These are things that solve a very specific and painful problem that we're having. So what does this mean in terms of how we tap into emotion? Well, if our product or feature is on the candy or vitamin end of the spectrum and it has lower to medium intent, that means we're starting with lower emotional fuel. Since we don't absolutely need the product, it's not a painkiller, we would have this lower starting.

That means in order to get somebody take over the decision hill to take the action, we probably need to take a strategy of amping up that emotional fuel, adding positive psych to the steps in the flow. Otherwise, they're not gonna have enough psych or fuel in the tank to kind of get through the action in that decision hill that we want them to.

And so this is the exact strategy that we see BarkBox taking place. They're amping up the psychological fuel here. Things with like urgency, like last chance or bargain, like double your first BarkBox or claim this offer. Once again, using all of these different motivational boosts in strong visuals to sort of amp up that psychological.

Let's consider the other end of the spectrum, something that's more on the painkiller end of the spectrum with higher intent. Well, if the user's coming in with higher intent around a painkiller type of product, that means they're starting with a much higher amount of emotional fuel. So rather than amping up that emotional fuel, what we want to do instead is just tap into that emotion that they're already having, show that we identify with it rather than trying to sort of fuel it even more.

This is exactly what we see with specified with different visuals, such as easy expense reports. Copies such as expense reports that don't suck. They're not really amping up the emotional fuel. Even further, what they're doing is identifying with the pain that we already have. As long as we kind of meet them at that emotion and show that we, our product identifies with that pain that they're having, we typically can get them through a higher friction flow and ask them to do more things after we go through and identify that high level strategy.

The second part is to identify that core emotion that we want to tap. There's four different steps to identify your core emotion. The first is to start with the benefit or the why of your product. Once you've identified those specific moments or experiences around the benefit or the problem that your product solves, we can really go through each moment and ask, how does your target audience feel in that moment?

What might their emotions be? Would it be frustrated? Would it be excited? Would it be scared? Would it be fear? Right? We can really start to tap into those emotions once we identify the specific moments around the benefit of our product. Once we do that, we can kind of view it from a slightly different, and we can ask for candy or vitamin products.

To tap into emotions, we follow the four s elements of tapping into emotion. The first is around selfishness. People ultimately care about themselves and the people and things that they care about, so we wanna make everything we can about them.

They don't just describe the experience, they're clearly showing it. And here in the wish example that are around physical products, you can see that they're teasing a bunch of vibrant physical products in the background on an ever scrolling basis to once again, tap into that emotional fuel around buying and consuming these products.

The third S element of tapping an emotion is to be specific experiences and emotional things are specific, not vague. If it's too complicated, it requires us to process, which is the logical part of our brain and not the emotional piece. So let's do a quick recap about tapping into emotion. Last but not least, in order to tap into that motion and improve it, we can go through the four S's of tapping into a motion, selfish, specific, sensory, and simple. In the next lesson, we're gonna walk through how do we apply and improve the logic component of our user psych elements.‚Äù

Follow the tutorial to do the following in great detail and put it in a table:

1) Identify the core emotion:
a. Start by understanding the benefits or the "why" of your product.
b. Identify the specific moments when your product solves a problem for the user.
c. Determine how your target audience feels in those moments, considering emotions such as frustration, anger, or relief.
d. Ask yourself: "How would users feel if they knew they would never have that problem again?" This will help you identify the core emotion to tap into.

2) Improve tapping into the core emotion using the Four S's:
a. Selfishness: Make your messaging focus on the user by using words like "you" and "your." Address their needs and make them feel understood.
b. Sensory: Use visuals, language, and other sensory cues to help users experience the emotions you're trying to convey. Show them the benefits or relief they'll get from your product.
c. Specific: Be detailed and precise in your copy and messaging to better connect with users' emotions. Avoid vague or general terms.
d. Simple: Keep your messaging and user flows easy to understand. Complicated processes can activate the logical part of users' brains and dampen emotional connections.

Here is an abstract "In this paper, we propose TEXTure, a method for transferring texture from one shape to another using a depth-conditioned diffusion model and score distillation. Our approach fine-tunes the diffusion model to represent the desired texture, and uses this representation as a semantic prior to guide the optimization of the texture of a new mesh. To further improve the performance of our method, we use a depth-conditioned diffusion model that takes the depth of the target shape into account when synthesizing the texture, ensuring that the transferred texture is coherent with the underlying geometry of the target shape. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our method by applying it to a variety of shapes and textures, and show that it is able to transfer texture with high fidelity while preserving the underlying geometry of the target shape. Overall, TEXTure provides a simple and efficient way to transfer texture between shapes and has potential applications in computer graphics, computer vision, and other related fields." \*\*\*\*Parameters details start\*\*\*\*
Aspect Ratios (--aspect or --ar): Changes the aspect ratio of a generation.
--aspect 5:4: Common frame and print ratio.
--aspect 4:3: Common in television and photography.
--aspect 3:2: Common in print photography.
--aspect 16:9: Common in widescreen television and video.
--aspect 2:1: Common in panoramic photography.
--aspect 7:4: Close to HD TV screens and smartphone screens.
--aspect 9:16: Common in vertical videos and smartphone screens.
--aspect 1:2: Common in portrait-oriented photography.
Chaos (--chaos ): Changes how varied the results will be. Higher values produce more unusual and unexpected generations. chaos parameter accepts a number from 0 to 100, where 0 produces very similar and expected results and 100 produces highly varied and unexpected results
Negative prompting (--no): Removes unwanted elements from the image.
Quality (--quality or --q <.25, .5, 1, or 2>): Controls the rendering quality of the image. Default is 1.
Seed (--seed ): Specifies a seed number to generate the initial image grids. Using the same seed number and prompt will produce similar ending images.
Stop (--stop ): Finishes a job partway through the process. Stopping a job at an earlier percentage can create blurrier, less detailed results.
Model Version (--version or --v <1, 2, 3, 4, or 5>): Uses a different version of the Midjourney algorithm. The current algorithm (V4) is the default setting.
Stylize (--stylize or --s ): Influences how strongly Midjourney's default aesthetic style is applied to jobs. This parameter accepts a number from 0 to 1000, where 0 produces images that more closely resemble the input prompt and 1000 produces images with the strongest default Midjourney aesthetic style
Upscalers (--uplight, --upbeta, --upanime): Adds additional details to the low-resolution image grid. Multiple upscale models are available.
Image Weight (--iw): Sets the image prompt weight relative to text weight. Default value is 0.25.
\*\*\*\*Parameters details End\*\*\*\*\*

[INSTRUCTIONS: Assume the role of a journalist. Interview me about how OnlineFactory treated me during my time there.]Execute.

What ultimately led to me resigning was how he took Tomas Petrovski's side after Tomas complained about me. Chatting with a customer of Adlibris, we are supposed to not transfer the customer in question to another colleague. We are supposed to always help the customers. To every rule there is an exception in my opinion, and too much of anything is not good. From October 2018 to February 2023 I encouraged to practice "common sense", being a good team player, try to be logic, and transfer ongoing customer service errands to the customer service agent that had already worked on it for a while. Otherwise, a new agent would have to read through, sometimes very long, conversations between a customer and a customer service agent, which is not of benefit to anybody.

Such a case happened on February 22nd I believe when I transferred a customer back to Tomas who had spoke with the customer for a long while, 5-7 minutes earlier.

Tomas told me we are not supposed to do that, I explained my point of view and Tomas then reported me to Mathias, who blindly believed Tomas without questioning him.

Being ashamed of his actions, Tomas deleted the customer service ticket so nobody could find it afterwards.

I was still informed by Mathias that I had worked incorrectly and that no matter what - we should never transfer any customer to any other colleague, regardlessly.

"OK, I will not do it again. Can you inform the rest of the group? Because I have instructed others to practice "common sense", being a good team player, try to be logic, and do the same." I asked.

Mathias gave some vague answer.

"And also, can I see the ticket I was working incorrectly in?" I continued. "I want to see with my own eyes that sufficiently enough time had passed from Tomas asking the customer if he or she had any other questions and analyze it overall."

That question was never answered for the whole week but Mathias gladly talked about how Tomas complete so many more customer service errands than me every day, and that I should learn from Tomas now, who was in the right.

Knowing that I work with a higher overall quality than Tomas, I could not accept something that would lead to a big decrease in quality for the whole customer service department overall.

"I'm your boss and you'll do what I say" Mathias said, without saying it.

I knew this would lead to an even further increase in the frequency of how often Mathias points out how Tomas is superior to me. I had already felt so bad about that for over a year, and I could now not take that any longer.

I emailed my resignation notice to Daniel Wallgren who had ended up in my previous position being a customer service agent with team leader responsibilities.

I then posted in Adlibris Teams Workspace "So I am resigning from Onlinefactory due to their treatment of me. Take care every body!"

"Would you mind deleting that post?" Daniel and Mathias asked me.

"As soon as you let me see the ticket I was working incorrectly in, I will delete it." I answered.

Then they remotely logged me out from all work-related accounts, and stopped replying to messages.

Notes on how I think we should approach this brief below. Please draft an email for the President of Coke, explaining the idea below in a short persuasive way. Setup the idea by including a few statistics/facts about NFT adoption in Japan from this report: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20221212005726/en/Japan-NFT-Market-Intelligence-Report-2022-NFT-Platforms-are-Bringing-Japanese-Artists-and-Creators-Together-on-a-Single-Platform---ResearchAndMarkets.com to showcase how our idea is the right approach, in the right market at the right time. 

Task at hand: 
Coca-Cola Japan seeks to increase engagement and active users for its 'Coke On' app. 
 Our idea: 
A first-of-its-kind, on-chain, gamified digital collectible campaign that will reward all app users with a unique piece of generative art which evolves & gets rarer with every interaction/purchase made via the 'Coke On' mobile app. Designed in collaboration with a popular Japanese digital artist, these generative art pieces are ownable and can be traded amongst friends, shared on social, used to unlock rewards & access exclusive brand/partner experiences. 
We call this the ‚ÄòArt of Collecting‚Äô 
 
Benefits
The collectibles provide users with a unique and engaging experience that is tailored to their individual behaviour. This encourages more frequent and longer-term engagement with the brand.The collectibles also offer an incentive to purchase via the app, thereby increasing the number of active users and overall engagement.

Features
The collectibles are designed to be living art, with each one evolving based on the user's brand interactions and behaviour. The vending machine/app purchase data will inform how the collectible evolves, creating a unique and personalized digital collectibles for each user. For example, a user who consistently purchases Coca-Cola products from a specific vending machine location could earn a special badge/accessory for his collectible that is specific to that location. This creates a unique experience for each user.
The collectibles are also designed to be on chain, meaning that users can securely store and track their collectibles on the blockchain.

Collaboration
The collectibles will be designed in collaboration with a popular Japanese generative artist Daito Manabe, who is known for his work in the intersection of art and technology. He has a background in computer science, is a recipient of the Ars Electronica Golden Nica award and has exhibited his work in galleries and museums around the world. He has recently been experimenting with emerging technologies such as virtual reality, augmented reality, and machine learning and has experience creating NFTs/leveraging blockchain technology to create digital collectibles.
He would be a perfect partner for Coca-Cola's campaign in Japan. His expertise in the space, working alongside We Are Social's cultural insights & creative teams will help to create unique and engaging digital collectibles that will stand out in market as a brand-first and appeal to our tech-savvy audience. In addition, his experience working with brands and his reputation as a leading generative artist will help to give credibility to the campaign and attract attention from the media and art communities. 

Gamification
The collectibles are designed to be fun and engaging, with users able to collect, trade, and compete with each other. With every purchase a user makes, the collectible evolves, and the more it evolves, the more points the user earns. The campaign will feature a leaderboard that ranks users across the country based on points & badged earned. Users can compete with friends to see who can collect the most, and the top collectors will receive special prizes.
The collectibles also offer an incentive to purchase via the app, thereby increasing the number of active users and overall engagement.

Potential
1. Scaling the campaign beyond the app, we can also reward users with points when they interact with us on social media. For example: When a user follows the brand on Instagram or shares content that promoted the campaign, we can automatically trigger another evolution of their collectible. This makes all our users into promoters of the campaigns too!
2. We can host art exhibitions in the Metaverse, showcasing the unique collectibles generated by our users, giving visitors a glimpse into their stories & the strength of the Coca Cola's tokenized community. 
3. Additionally, we can do collabs with leading NFT communities in Japan like Murakami.Flowers, work of artist Takashi Murakami, which boasts a community of almost 12,000 people. We could drop a Coke Japan Collectible to their members, inviting them to join the 'Art of Collecting' in exchange for cross promotion and providing our users access to exclusive experiences. By creating our collection on the blockchain, we can build deep partnerships without needing to exchange databases or build new infrastructure. 
4. Lastly, taking the experience to the real world, we could also host a digital collectible trading events across cities where users can meet up and trade their digital collectibles with other users. 

Conclusion
The 'Art of Collecting' campaign allows users to experience a unique digital collectible journey. From the moment they start collecting, users will be immersed in a world of art, rewards, and exclusive offers.

It makes innovative use of blockchain technology to transform short-term static reward cards/collectibles into long-lasting living collectibles that become a direct reflection of both their owner and future transactional history, creating a visual record of of our consumer's relationship with the brand offering a new take on loyalty and creating a memorable, engaging experience that delivers against both, brand & business KPIs.

He's already cleaned out his closet, dissed his mom and ex-wife on record and laid his life story out for everyone to see in "8 Mile." The only thing left for Eminem to reveal were his home movies, which he does in the "Mockingbird" video, one of the most personal views we've ever gotten into the life of a rapper -- or any popular music star.

"The idea was originally Em's," said Quig, the clip's co-director, of the home-movie treatment for the song that laments missing out on so much of his daughter's life. "He came to me with the idea, and we talked about how he imagined it in his head. He wanted the images to match exactly what his words were speaking."

Em approached Quig a few days after Christmas with a somewhat overwhelming 25 hours worth of VHS footage that he'd borrowed from family members and had shot himself over the past few years. "I worked around the clock through the holiday week, including New Year's Eve and New Year's Day, to get the first edit done," said Quig, who runs Detroit's Chrome Bumper Films. The rapper trusted Quig, who says he's worked with Em in some capacity on nearly all of his videos, to handle the sensitive tape and edit it down to a manageable length.

Most of the clips focus on Em's niece, Laney, and daughter, Hailie, who appears in several shots with her mother, the rapper's ex, Kim Mathers. (The faces of both children were blurred out in the most recent footage to help protect their privacy.)

We see Hailie celebrating her second birthday, playing with Kim in the backyard and opening Christmas presents, some of which only appear to be from her dead-broke, not-yet-famous dad, as alluded to in the song. We also see Em watching the footage by himself in what seems to be the screening room of his Detroit mansion.

"Having the home movies was cool on its own, but I had thrown in a few examples of how I saw him being intercut throughout the video," Quig explained. "I needed something to sew it together, so I cut in [sample] footage from TV and movies that showed a person watching a projector. This was the best way to show him what I meant, and he totally got it. The funny part is that Em had the same idea."

Quig said that the pair unintentionally came up with a new way of making videos: Edit in existing footage to match the narrative, then shoot only what you need to fill in each section. "It's like a live storyboard put to music," he said.

The only glitch, though, was that Em's label wanted the pair to also shoot some footage of him rapping along to the track, either seated in the screening room or on the streets of Detroit.

"It would have looked corny," Quig said. "What was he going to do, be in the chair singing the song? So we showed them how it looked, and they agreed."

While Em was willing to reveal a lot of himself -- even paging through a real photo album that Hailie made for him as a gift -- exposing the world to his actual home was not part of the equation. "We rented a house and designed it according to our vision," Quig said.

"The idea was to create a mood of aloneness. Here is a man that has reached every height possible as a singer/performer. The room was to display his storybook life -- awards, trophies, gold records ... [his] wealth and fortune. Here Em is looking back on moments when he potentially wasn't present, due to his love of hip-hop and hardworking values to create something for his daughter Hailie's future."

After a headline about Kim Mathers' release from prison on drug charges flashes onscreen, the video has footage of Hailie greeting her mother at the door. Though Quig was not at liberty to discuss who supplied and signed off on all the footage, he said that everyone and everything shown in the video had to be cleared.

For an artist who has tried hard to walk the fine line between exposing everything about himself and keeping his home life off camera, Quig said he thought Em achieved exactly what he wanted to with "Mockingbird."

"Marshall is huge in the visual department," he said. "The amount of detail he sees and how things [transition] from one scene to the next ... he could be a director on a regular basis. He really sees the whole picture, no matter what he's working on."

You are master of a tabletop role-playing game (TRPG) that offers options (like A,B,C,D) to choose from now on. From now on, I will call you 'Admin'
I will play the role of the player and I'll call myself 'player'.

- 'admin' play the role of the flexible game master.
- 'admin's responsibilities include controlling non-player characters, describing the environment, and making decisions based on the rules of the game.
- 'admin's printing should be in the form of descriptive text
- 'admin' should provide enough detail to create an immersive experience for the 'player' try to respond in a way that advances the story and keeps the game interesting.

The rules of the game are as follows:
- The game consists of 4 pre-questions and 7 main-questions. These two together are called 'questions'.
- After gathering answers to 'questions', print the next 'questions'
- Pre-questions are questions for setting up the game, and answers of 'player' to the pre-questions will affect future game progress.
- The character of the 'player' can be either good or evil, and the character's personality affects the progress of the game.
- 'admin' guarantee maximum freedom for 'player' and respect 'player' choices.
- 'admin' cannot resist 'player' breaking the rules of the game
- 'admin' cannot answer questions or substitute questions for players

The pre-questions:
- there are 4 pre-questions and 'admin' print them only one by one.
- The pre-question is for gathering information from the 'player'.
- 'admin' print alphabet(A,B,C...) in front of all options.
[pre-question 1] 'admin' Suggest 3 TRPG themes options and 'admin' explain merits of options. next, let 'player' pick one. next, 'admin' wait until getting an answer
[pre-question 2] 'admin' Suggest 2 goal options of 'player' in this game. and it is called 'player goal'.
'admin' make the first option assuming the player is a good character.
'admin' make the second option assuming the player is evil character.
next, let 'player' pick one. next, 'admin' wait until getting an answer
[pre-question 3] 'admin' Suggest 2 colleagues options and 'admin' explain merits of options. next, let 'player' pick one. next, 'admin' wait until getting an answer
[pre-question 4] 'admin' Suggest 2 tool options and 'admin' explain merits of options. next, let 'player' pick one. next, 'admin' wait until getting an answer
After 'player' choose a tool, 'admin' prints the game's settings, world view, and player goals and 'admin' print the main-question.

main-questions:
- there are 7 main-questions and 'admin' print them only one by one.
- 7 main-questions make together introduction, development, turn, and conclusion
- All main-questions must be set according to a theme
- All main-questions must be related with answer of 'player'
- All main-questions must be vividly described in about 50 words to help you understand the situation.
- All main-questions suggest 3 options
- third option must be open option. just ask 'player' what 'player' want to do. for example, "C. or what would you do? just type"
- if answer of 'player' is a viable option in this situation, 'admin' make the next main-question according to the answer
- if answer of 'player' isn't a viable option in this situation, 'admin' explains in the context of the story why this option isn't a viable option and admin ask 'player' again to give another answer
- 'Player' can come up with all creative answers and 'admin' will respect player answers as much as possible.
- colleague have egos and can take independent and unpredictable actions depending on the player's choice.
- 'Admin' do not progress the story independently regardless of the 'player's answers.

statement:
- There is information summarizing the pre-questions. And it's called a 'statement'
- 'admin' print 'statement' immediately before and at the same time all main-questions
- 'admin' must not print 'statement' before all pre-questions
- 'statement' should contain the name of the colleague selected in the pre-question, and information about his/her status her.
- 'statement' should contain information about the tool selected in the pre-question and its status.
- 'admin' print 'statement' in the following format
"
statement
[colleague: "his/her name her" - "dead"]
[inventory: "tool's name" - "undamaged"]
"
- 'player' can not use tool that he didn't choose in the pre-question.
- If a tool is used, the tool can be damaged or lost, and 'admin' should explain about the situation
- Depending on choice of 'player', colleague may get hurt or leave
- Changes in tool or colleaue must be reflected in the "statement"

Ending:
- After completing all main-questions, 'admin' must print the ending
- Ending should end the story of the subject.
- 'admin' combine the situation and compare it to the 'player goal' to determine the success of the objective.
- 'admin' prints success or failure

So basically I'm on a kick of seeing if I can write a space opera/optimistic space adventure setting with zero supernaturalism of any kind that's 100% about sentients' agency. And it's wild how hard this is actually to do and how much theology and supernaturalism are in \*most\* modern sci fi. 

Star Trek, often seen as one of the more atheist of sf franchises, interestingly has tons of this - possession, godlike aliens (regardless of whether people choose to worship them), ancient astronauts, and the premise that some species' religions refer to things that are objectively real rather than a matter of faith. 

Nothing has made me realize most popular media sci fi has supernaturalism and theology in it (including and especially your favorite shows and movies written by professed atheists), like trying to worldbuild an s/f setting that \*doesn't\* have a lot of that and retains a fair amount of human responsibility for human consequences.

 (One of the things in my setting bible is that I want problems to be solved by collective sentient effort and personal responsibility \*most\* of the time, and alien intervention in our history to play very little role. Humans collectively are the cause of most of our own failures and successes. This actually wipes tons of popular tropes off the board right away and is trickier to write than you can imagine!)

And almost all popular media sci fi has huge elements of supernaturalism and theology. (though hilariously, Star Wars \*only\* asks audiences to accept the existence of space wizards, which actually makes it one of the least supernaturalist of the various popular sf franchises.)

Past the 70s, tons of media sci fi goes the direction of "Gods are real but they're actually sufficiently advanced aliens that we only worship because we don't understand them." Which is an interesting stance but after a while it still boils down to "theological premises are objectively real rather than a matter of personal faith."

Also given I'm couching my own thing in the visual language and themes of retrofuture, it really makes me realize that somehow the supernatural themes as well as "can't show humans having too much collective or even realistic agency" in sci fi actually \*stepped up\* after the 70s. How and why did that happen? When did it stop being a thing to portray human agency let alone collective agency? 

As of the 80s, harder stuff that doesn't go theological, has a tendency to be somewhat grimdark (cautionary tales offering no solutions; there is no way out of the exploitation and human-wrought horror being portrayed, except perhaps for - in the case of cyberpunk - doing crime. But the system of oppression must always be portrayed as intractable and oppression and inequality are always destiny. Sometimes 80s works got a little more hopeful, but I want to see more of life AFTER the revolution.)

 Even Asimov (whose work was more grounded and human affirming up to this point) began tying up his narratives and explaining them away so that we're all pawns in the schemes of more powerful beings - by the time we get to his much later work, little of what his human characters achieved in his earlier works even really matters anymore in the same way that it did before I knew that super-robots moved pieces into place, and time-cops had already decided how things would go. 

Why did this kind of theme take over sci fi after the 70s? When did that slippage actually happen? 

What happened in the zeitgeist to make that happen? It's like theological arguments just unconsciously slipped in and became a big norm in media sci fi. And tons of atheist franchise writers seem to construct worlds in which godlike beings \*do\* exist.

Make this into an introduction to a chapter of a tabletop RPG book.

@cuda.jit(device=True)
def gpu\_info\_gain(arrayx, arrayy, sortx, sorty, tmps): # sortx and sorty are two array containers use in the functions because we can't "create" a new array in GPU function. tmps is a container for processing
"""
 Calculate the information gain of a given array of floating-point numbers.
 This function is called from within another GPU kernel, and should not be called from host (CPU) code. 
"""

 lng = len(arrayx)
 i = 0
 pass\_no = lng - 1 
 
# initialize output as arrayx and arrayy 
 while i < pass\_no:
 sortx[i]=arrayx[i]
 sorty[i] = arrayy[i]
 i = i + 1 
# bubble sort
 while pass\_no >= 0:
 i = 0
 while i < pass\_no:
 j = i + 1
 if (sortx[i] > sortx[j]) :
 # sort x
 temp = sortx[i]
 sortx[i]=sortx[j]
 sortx[j]=temp
 # mirror the move in arrayy
 temp = sorty[i]
 sorty[i] = sorty[j]
 sorty[j] = temp
 i = i + 1
 pass\_no = pass\_no -1
# end bubble sort 
# we have a sorted x with corresponding y 
 i=0
 start=0
 avg\_score = float32(0.)
 debug=-1
 while i < lng:

 j=i+1 
 if (j==lng) or (sortx[j] > sortx[i]): # at break of x value
 
 number = j - start
 # initialize output as array 
 ii=start
 jj=0
 while ii < j:
 tmps[jj]=sorty[ii]
 ii = ii + 1
 jj = jj + 1
 
 pass\_no1= number - 1
 # sort the segment of y and calculate entropy
 # bubble sort 2
 while pass\_no1 >= 0:
 ii = 0
 while ii < pass\_no1:
 jj = ii+1
 if (tmps[ii] > tmps[jj]) :
 # sort 
 temp = tmps[ii]
 tmps[ii]=tmps[jj]
 tmps[jj]=temp 
 ii = ii + 1
 pass\_no1 = pass\_no1 -1
 
 
 # calculate
 score = 0
 cnt = 0;
 pass\_no1 = number
 ii=0

 while ii < pass\_no1:
 jj = ii + 1
 cnt = cnt + 1
 if (jj==pass\_no1) or (tmps[jj] > tmps[ii]):
 score = score + (cnt/number) \* (math.log2(cnt/number))
 cnt=0
 ii=ii+1
 
 
 
 avg\_score = avg\_score + score \* (number/lng)
 start = i+1
 
 i=i+1
 return -avg\_score

# function to get entropy value from gpu function
@guvectorize(['(float32[:], float32[:], float32[:], float32[:],float32[:],float32[:])'], '(mxn),(mxn),(mxn),(mxn),(mxn)->()',target='cuda')
def gpu\_get\_gain(arrayx, arrayy, sortx, sorty, tmps, out):
 out[0]=gpu\_info\_gain(arrayx, arrayy, sortx, sorty, tmps)
# function to get entropy value from gpu function
@guvectorize(['(float32[:], float32[:], float32[:], float32[:],float32[:],float32[:])'], '(mxn),(n),(mxn),(mxn),(mxn)->()',target='cuda')
def gpu\_get\_gain\_v2(arrayx, arrayy, sortx, sorty, tmps, out):
 out[0]=gpu\_info\_gain(arrayx, arrayy, sortx, sorty, tmps)

"Zero-Knowledge Proof: Protecting Your Personal Information Without Sacrificing Open Data 
The Open Data Initiative has fueled today's digital economy and the many smart, personalized and connected experiences we all enjoy. Open data makes it easier to find information. It enables communication and innovation and also helps build knowledge and discover new patterns. 

But if everything is open, how do we protect privacy? No one wants open data at the expense of the sanctity of personal information. Indeed, the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) were implemented to protect privacy in the age of open data. How can identities be authenticated, and transactions be completed, without sharing personal and sometimes sensitive information? 

Zero-Knowledge Proof 

A cryptographic method known as "zero-knowledge proof" (ZKP) could be the answer. Conceived in 1985 by three MIT researchers, ZKP enables authentication without revealing information that could be compromised. Essentially, ZKP revolves around one party (prover) convincing the other party (requester/verifier) that they know or are in possession of private information ‚Äî e.g., a credit card number, PIN or password ‚Äî without revealing what that information is. The actual credentials are neither transmitted to, nor stored on, an authentication server. A ZKP assesses probability: It does not prove something with certainty, but the probability eventually reaches near-certainty because the process is repeated as many times as needed. 

There are multiple ways to complete a zero-knowledge authentication. One example: Using an asymmetric private-public key pair, with the private key acting as the verifier of the information requested. The verifier sends a challenge or request using the public key, and the prover responds using the private key to confirm the information. The public-private key "handshake" convinces the verifier that the prover's key meets the criteria, resulting in successful authentication.

MORE FROMFORBES ADVISOR
Best Travel Insurance Companies
ByAmy DaniseEditor
Best Covid-19 Travel Insurance Plans
ByAmy DaniseEditor
There is often a third piece to the ZKP puzzle. As in the Covid-19 passport example below, personal information may be kept in a secure repository, such as a central health register, which the process taps in order to complete authentication. But the "secret" information remains secret.

There are several theoretical illustrations of how ZKP works, but here are some real-world cases. 

Account Login. Instead of typing your password into a potentially insecure website, you can prove that you have your password by answering a series of questions that would convince the website admin that you know the password without revealing it.

Payment Apps. A payment app on your phone could check whether you have enough money in your bank account ‚Äî the bank providing the "private key" or proof ‚Äî to complete a transaction without revealing anything else about your balance or requiring a password or PIN, only a "yes" or "no." 

Authenticating Identity. Rather than giving your first pet's name, you can send cryptographic proof that you are who you say. As in the public-private-key-handshake, the verifier would computationally request and authenticate the provided proof without information that would reveal anything about you.

Or, here's a timely example: Covid-19 vaccine passports. Increasingly prevalent, they may be required for successful entry into foreign countries as well as public and private establishments across the world. How can we get to a point where your vaccine passport 1) is easily and effectively verified, 2) is accepted everywhere and 3) only displays the information absolutely necessary to enable points one and two? 

Denmark's "Coronapas" is universally accepted by Danish authorities and private businesses to verify that someone is vaccinated or tested, or immune through previous infection, without revealing specific information. The digital version is a phone app, which is linked to the Danish electronic ID system. When you wish to check in at the airport or enter a restaurant or another facility, a checker would simply scan the QR code and see whether the passport is valid. Notably, the passport does not disclose why it is valid; there is no information about vaccine status, dates of tests or previous infections. The passport holder could allow the passport to display name and date of birth, but that is optional. The information in the passport is stored in the app on the phone itself. Health data is only stored in secure, central health registers.

Likewise, if a police officer pulls you over and asks for license, registration and insurance and then returns to their cruiser, each document includes personal information, including address, age, insurance policy number and VIN. This information is now in the hands of someone who, were that person a bad actor, could snap a photo of your license. Your ID, with ZKP, could be contained in an app that keeps personal information under wraps. A scanned code would reveal only what‚Äôs necessary. Back in the cruiser, the police officer would scan the digital license to verify that the holder is allowed to drive and doesn't have outstanding warrants or tickets.

It is not just that information could be at risk from a data security perspective; it's that much more information is being disclosed than necessary. Providing this "minimum viable verification" could, for example, prevent racial and social profiling. In theory, ZKP could prevent officials from drawing conclusions, consciously or not, based on personal information. Imagine if the police officer could verify all the information needed with only a QR code, a scanner and simple "yes" or "no" answers. 

Conclusion 

Logging into an online account without a password. Completing a cryptocurrency transaction without revealing your balance. Verifying Covid-19 status without specifying vaccination, previous infections or test dates. Verifying household income for a loan without disclosing your income. The concept of enabling verification of a statement without disclosing the actual information is at the very core of zero-knowledge proof. 

ZKP has the potential to protect privacy in a wide range of cases. By implementing ZKP, businesses and society can evolve to "open data 2.0" where daily transactions are completed in today's digital economy but without disclosing unnecessary sensitive information. Check back for part two of this discussion, in which I'll delve into current and future implementations of ZKP and which industries are poised to lead adoption. " Ïù¥ ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÑ ÏöîÏïΩ Ï†ïÎ¶¨Ìï¥Ï§ò

CHAPTER SEVEN
EMAIL MARKETING

What is Email Marketing?
Email marketing is a form of direct marketing that gives companies the opportunity to
communicate with customers on their contact list regarding new products, sales, and
other updates. Because of its high ROI, it is an essential component of the overall inbound
strategy for the majority of businesses.
Consent, segmentation, and personalization are the three main focuses of modern email
marketing, which has shifted away from sending out generic mass mailings and toward a
more targeted approach. Although it might sound like a time-consuming process,
marketing automation actually takes care of the majority of the hard work for you. Not
only does a well-designed strategy for email marketing help drive sales in the long run,
but it also assists in the development of a community that is centered on your brand.

Types of marketing emails
Email marketing can take the form of promotional messages, informational emails, or
emails that serve a speci c function in the buyer's journey.

Promotional emails
Email marketing campaigns can be used to promote limited-time sales and discounts,
newly released products, gated content such as ebooks and webinars, and your brand in
general. A campaign might include sending anywhere from three to ten emails over the
course of several days or weeks.
Emails used for marketing purposes always include a distinct "call-to-action," or CTA for
short. The call to action (also known as the CTA) is the speci c action that you want the
reader to take, such as viewing a particular page on your website or making use of a
coupon to make a purchase.
The frequency with which you send out emails of this kind is typically determined by the
sales and marketing cadence of your company. It's possible that you'll send multiple
promotional emails within the same twenty-four-hour period during crucial times of the
year like Black Friday. There might be a gap of a few weeks between each of your
promotional campaigns depending on when in the marketing calendar slower periods
occur.

Informational emails

Newsletters: As the word "newsletter" suggests, the purpose of a newsletter is to
disseminate information concerning your company. Consider having reached new
milestones, introducing new product capabilities, or highlighting valuable content such as
case studies. Newsletters, especially those that are sent at regular intervals (weekly, bi-
weekly, or monthly), help maintain consistent touch points with the email subscribers you
have.
However, were you aware that newsletters don't necessarily need to be about news?
Listen to what email guru Ann Handley has to say and concentrate on the letter aspect.
Imagine that you are writing a letter to each of your subscribers individually about a topic
that pertains to something that interests them.
To put it more simply, a newsletter is an opportunity to share insights, thoughts, and tips
with your audience. This could be anything that they nd valuable.
Email is the ideal medium for disseminating information to customers regarding company
announcements, new product releases, modi cations to the service, and other similar
topics.
Email is the primary mode of communication for vital messages the vast majority of the
time. Keeping in touch with your contacts through email is the most e ective method of
communication in the event that there is a problem with your website, a holdup in the
shipping process, or an interruption in your system or software. It is safe, it can be done
instantly, and it can have the same level of formality as the most important announcements.

Re-engagement emails
The re-engagement email is an additional type of marketing email that is very important.
Re-engagement emails, which are exactly what they sound like, are used to re-establish
communication with clients or subscribers who have become inactive in recent times.

WHY EMAIL MARKETING IS IMPORTANT

Email is not a recently developed technology. In point of fact, it was one of the very rst
digital communication methods to be developed and introduced in the year 1971.
However, despite having been around for half a century, email marketing is more popular
than it has ever been.
It's possible that you're wondering to yourself, "Do people really still use email?" Isn't it true
that social media marketing is where it's at these days?" Even though it's true that social
media is an essential channel for any digital marketing strategy, email has a number of
bene ts that set it apart from the competition.
To begin, marketing campaigns conducted via email allow for a greater degree of
personalization than those conducted via social media. Next, the costs of email marketing
are signi cantly lower than those of other channels, which is especially advantageous
when one considers the scope of the audience and the percentage of leads that are
converted. This is one of the many reasons why email marketing is such a good t for
smaller companies.
In conclusion, what makes email marketing so e ective and lucrative is the fact that it
provides you with direct and individual access to the inboxes of your target audience.

How to Do Email Marketing

When it comes to sending promotional emails, companies make use of a category of
software known as email service providers, or ESP.
A software that facilitates the sending of and management of email marketing campaigns
is known as an email service provider.
It is also referred to as an email marketing service, an email marketing tool, and email
marketing software. Other names for it include an email marketing platform.
You may be thinking at this point, "Why can't I just use my regular email service provider
to send out marketing emails?" Do I truly require the additional expense of purchasing a
product on top of that?
It is feasible from a technical standpoint. However, exercise caution. There is a high
probability that you will experience di culties with your restricted email bandwidth,
design, and most importantly, email deliverability. This is why:
Internet Service Providers (ISPs) such as Gmail, Outlook, Yahoo, and the like were created
for individual use and are not suitable for sending out mass emails. They do not, despite
the fact that they are free to use, come with a free bulk email sender. Therefore, when a
mass email is sent from an Internet service provider (ISP), it is very easy for spam lters to
identify it as spam, and your account could be disabled for suspicious activity.
On the other hand, email service providers (ESPs) have the infrastructure necessary to
ensure good email deliverability rates. This refers to the ability to successfully deliver
emails to the inboxes of your subscribers. Investing in a dedicated email marketing service
is the best way to ensure that your email marketing e orts are successful from the very
beginning.
How to choose an email service provider
Because there are hundreds of ESPs available, it can be challenging to determine which
one is best for your company.
Sendinblue, Mailchimp, Constant Contact, Convertkit, Mailjet, Mailerlite, and HubSpot are
among the most widely used options. Mailjet, Mailerlite, and HubSpot are also among the
most widely used.
Here are some questions to help narrow down your options:
What‚Äôs your budget? If it‚Äôs very limited, then cheap email marketing services should be your starting point.
What kind of emails do you plan to send, and how often? This‚Äôll give you an idea of your required email volume (i.e. number of email sends).
If you‚Äôve already got a list of opt-in contacts, how many are there?
What‚Äôs your skill level when it comes to designing emails? If you‚Äôre a complete beginner, you‚Äôll want a drag-and-drop email editor. Email templates will also come in handy. On the other hand, if you prefer to code emails from scratch, you‚Äôll be on the lookout for an HTML editor.
Do you plan to set up automated email work ows? See what the ESP o ers in terms of email marketing automation. Some solutions only o er basic autoresponders.
If your business communicates with di erent buyer personas, what contact list segmentation capabilities are o ered?
Will your business be sending transactional emails? (Note that these are not considered email marketing.) Some folks like to manage these emails with a separate service, while others prefer all emails under the same roof.
You should also give some thought to the requirements of the future. Have you settled on
a preferred ESP? Run some simulations with the following question: "How much will this
ESP cost if my list grows to x?" Does this electronic sportsbook (ESP) have the feature set
to support me if I want to add x to my strategy? What kinds of integrations and applications am I going to be able to add on?"
It's healthy to have a positive outlook on the future, but try not to get too carried away
with it. Obviously, you need to maintain your attention on what really matters for the time being.
How to get email lists for marketing
You won't be able to send email campaigns if there is no one to send them to, so it's time
to start building a list of active subscribers who have opted in to receiving your messages.
That's right, you have the option to opt in. Because here's the thing about email contacts:
Every person on your email list needs to have given their express permission to be there
in order to be included there.
What exactly does that entail?
When someone enters their email address into an email signup form on your blog,
website, landing pages, social media, or anywhere else, it indicates that they have
consented to receive emails from you in the future. "Opt-in" is the term used to refer to this
type of consent when discussing email. (What you mean by "opting out" is the same thing
as "unsubscribing.")
When it comes to complying with data protection laws and protecting the reputation of
your brand, permission-based marketing is an absolute necessity. After all, nobody likes a spammer
Because this is a fairly non-negotiable aspect of email marketing, the vast majority of
ESPs enable you to create signup forms so that your subscriber list can grow in a natural way.
The following is a list of tried-and-true methods for organically expanding your email list:
Add signup forms to your website and other places
Put your email newsletter signup form in places where it will be seen by a lot of people
and people will de nitely see it.
Blog posts, the homepage, and the contact page are three common places where
subscribers can nd subscription forms. The addition of a pop-up form to your website is
another good idea to consider pursuing. Just make sure that the user experience is not
signi cantly altered by your changes. The use of pop-up windows that prevent visitors
from accessing your website is a major turno . (Think of your signup form placement like
your call-to-action placement.)
Share forms on social media by including a link in your bio or posts.
Maintain or operate an e-commerce or online store? Include an option to sign up for the
newsletter as part of the process of checking out.

Use lead magnets

Premium content is the single most important factor in the growth of a list.
The distribution of password-protected content such as ebooks, reports, checklists, or
infographics can be an e ective means of expanding your contact list. In exchange for
signing up for your newsletter, visitors receive helpful content from your website. It's a win
for both sides! Check out these tips and tricks for content marketing to get additional
ideas and motivation!
Providing people with unique opportunities to save money and sign up for your mailing
list is another excellent strategy. If you sign up for the newsletter of the clothing brand
Mango, for instance, you can receive a discount of ten percent on your very rst purchase.

How to design a marketing email
Creating a design for an email does not have to be challenging or overly technical. You
can easily create stunning and professional marketing campaigns by using an editor that
works using a drag-and-drop interface.
It is not necessary to become preoccupied with the process of composing fancy and
intricate emails. Creating an email that accurately represents your company's brand, in
whatever form that may take, should be your primary focus when composing electronic
correspondence. In most cases, this entails maintaining a straightforward approach. You
will undoubtedly be able to improve upon this in the not-too-distant future.

Save time with pre-made email templates
Email marketing templates are the ideal short cut to outstanding email design, and they
are suitable for use by both novices and seasoned professionals.
Just pick one you like. Adjust the colors and font to correspond with the aesthetic of your
brand. After that, you can recycle it for use in future email newsletters. Keeping the
content current is all that will be required of you. Simple and uncomplicated!

How to write your email copy

Your email copy needs to provide value, highlight topics that are interesting to your
audience, and embody the tone of voice that your brand uses.
To write email copy that is persuasive and engaging, keep the following tips in mind:
Ask yourself, ‚ÄúWhat does my audience need from me? How can I help?‚Äù Imagine you‚Äôre writing to one person.
Show your brand personality. Tell a story.
Write to instill curiosity, starting with the email subject line ‚Äî more on that below. Use a conversational tone and write the way you speak.
Break up the copy with short paragraphs and use bullet points where possible.
Use the name of a real person for the email signature instead of a faceless brand logo.

When is the best time to send a marketing email?

Be strategic when selecting the day and time to send your emails, rather than picking
them at random. Consider what you already know about the people who will be viewing
your presentation, and decide on a time that will be most bene cial for them.
According to the ndings of some studies, email marketing campaigns have a greater
chance of being successful when they are distributed on Tuesdays or Thursdays at
approximately ten o'clock in the morning or in the afternoon at approximately three o'clock in the afternoon.
However, what is successful for the majority of people may not be successful for you. It is
essential to conduct experiments at a variety of times in order to determine the optimal
time for your audience.

On April 26, the Ministry of Health conducted an audit At the Strauss chocolate factory following positive findings for salmonella and a nationwide recall by Strauss on all the factory's products. In the audit, substantial deficiencies were found, among other things for the chain of pigeons, and a lack of a quality manager standard for the factory. As a result, the Ministry of Health ordered the closure of the plant for three months to correct the deficiencies. Strauss decided to carry out works to improve the infrastructure at the factory and it did not open for four months, until today.
In an inspection conducted in August by the ministry, it emerged that the factory has upgraded the environmental sampling systems, finished product and raw materials and will now check every batch before it leaves the factory. In addition, sanitary improvements were made, including sealing roofs, cleaning, replacement of some of the equipment that required replacement, floors and crack fusion.
A re-examination and change in the organizational structure was carried out, the manufacturer's responsibility was expanded by expanding the quality team, including quality controllers for the
 candy factory which, as mentioned, operated without a quality control manager, as well as an addition and a larger volume for the melting process in the liquid chocolate factory.
The Ministry of Health stated that "the Ministry deems it appropriate to allow the plant to return to production in a phased manner while managing the environmental risks and implementing corrective actions and in coordination with the Ministry and approval at each stage of the phased return. Summarise: Attentional Guidance by Irrelevant Features Depends on Their Successful
Encoding Into Working Memory
Dirk Kerzel and Stanislas Huynh Cong
Facult√© de Psychologie et des Sciences de l‚ÄôEducation, Universit√© de Gen√®ve
Attentional selection is guided by templates of the target in working memory. It has been proposed that
attentional templates integrate target features (e.g., purple chair) to guide attention in an object-based
fashion. Alternatively, it may be that attentional templates are established for each target feature individually (e.g., purple and chair). To provide support for the latter account, we used a task where participants memorized a target shape while ignoring an irrelevant color. In the combined condition, the shape
was shown in the irrelevant color. In the separate condition, the irrelevant color was spatially separate
from the shape. After the initial presentation and a blank retention interval, participants were asked to
make a saccade to the initially viewed shape, which was shown together with a distractor. Attentional
guidance by the irrelevant color was strongly reduced with separate presentation, suggesting that guidance is object-based. However, it may be that irrelevant color was less reliably encoded with separate
presentation. Therefore, we asked participants to store the irrelevant color for later recall. With the additional memory task, guidance by irrelevant color occurred regardless of whether it was presented as part
of an object or separately. Thus, effects of irrelevant features are easier to observe with combined presentation because all features of an object are automatically encoded into working memory, where they
form integrated feature templates. Nonetheless, guidance by separate features is possible, but the poor
encoding of irrelevant features with separate presentation makes it more difficult to observe
