Below are questions and answers from an interview with the CEO of ‚ÄòPlastic Arc‚Äô, a Cafe24 customer.
Based on the information below, please write content to be posted on the Cafe24 blog from the perspective of the brand's growth process.

Q: Please tell us the meaning of your brand name.
Answer: Ark means Noah's Ark. In a world overflowing with plastic waste, the end of the world is drawing near. So we got the name because we said we would melt this plastic and make a plastic ark to save mankind.

Q: Please tell us how and when you started creating an online shopping mall.
A: Through the documentary, I realized that environmental problems are much more serious than I thought. One day, thinking that it could have an impact on the end of my life, I decided to take action. Plastic trash is overflowing, but I started a business using waste plastic because I thought I could make a small change with this plastic, which is always around me.

Q: Please tell us about the products you sell and your business overview.
A: I tried to make environmental protection a cultural trend in order to approach people who are not interested in environmental issues in a friendly way. Since there is nothing that can create a culture as quickly as fashion culture, we are developing a brand by combining fashion. Wanting recycled plastic products to be used closely in daily life, it started as a planter item, launched a cell phone case, and plans to expand to pet products in the future.

Q: What was the hardest thing about running an online shopping mall and how did you overcome it?
A: It was very difficult to manufacture and commercialize without any expertise in plastics. Waste plastic design pattern technology was a technology that did not exist before, so R&D was almost impossible. I tend to come here on my own, so I translated, read, and studied overseas papers, and I was convinced that it was possible. In the process, I made samples myself and suffered burns all over my body, but I met a company that said it was possible and was able to produce products.

Q: Can you tell us your company's growth story, including key metrics like revenue and membership?
Answer: In addition to consumers and followers who were interested in environmental protection, we are experiencing an increase in interest in brands, such as other brands recently taking an interest in plastic arc. Recently, as famous celebrities use Plastic Ark's products, the brand is growing further.

Question: What advice would you give to someone starting an online shopping mall?
Answer: If you have a desire to do something in your heart, I hope you do it as a movement or as an action, even if it is not necessarily a business. That way, you will not have any regrets later.

Q: How do you differentiate yourself from competing brands?
A: We are manufacturing products with technology that implements a certain design (pattern) with waste plastic.
Q: What is the company's future growth strategy and expansion plans?
Answer:- The mission of the brand is not simply to produce products by recycling waste plastic, but to achieve the circulation of resources. If you send Plastic Arc products or general plastic containers to Plastic Arc, we operate a reward program that accumulates points on the Plastic Arc website, and we want to activate this. If there is a place where a lot of plastic is consumed and can be collected, such as schools or apartments, we plan to carry out a collaborative project.

Q: Do you have plans to go abroad?
Answer: At the start of the business, overseas sales were considered as the focus, but it was held due to various variables (Corona, Ukraine). In the future, Cafe24 plans to carry out full-fledged overseas sales through the English website.

The NSW HIA Lump Sum contract is subject to the Home Building Act. Here is an extract of Section 3B of the Home Building Act 1989 (NSW). Just remember this information for now. I will message you instructions in later messages. If you understand this instruction, limit your reply by saying the word: "acknowledged".

HOME BUILDING ACT 1989 - SECT 3B
Date of completion of residential building work
3B Date of completion of residential building work
(1A) This section does not apply to residential building work to which section 3C applies.
Note : Section 3C provides for the date of completion of new buildings in strata schemes.
(1) The completion of residential building work occurs on the date that the work is complete within the meaning of the contract under which the work was done.
(2) If the contract does not provide for when work is complete (or there is no contract), the completion of residential building work occurs on
"practical completion" of the work, which is when the work is completed except for any omissions or defects that do not prevent the work from being reasonably capable of being used for its intended purpose.
(3) It is to be presumed (unless an earlier date for practical completion can be established) that practical completion of residential building work occurred on the earliest of whichever of the following dates can be established for the work--
(a) the date on which the contractor handed over possession of the work to the owner,
(b) the date on which the contractor last attended the site to carry out work (other than work to remedy any defect that does not affect practical completion),
(c) the date of issue of an occupation certificate under the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 that authorises commencement of the use or occupation of the work,
(d) (in the case of owner-builder work) the date that is 18 months after the issue of the owner-builder permit for the work.
(4) If residential building work comprises the construction of 2 or more buildings each of which is reasonably capable of being used and occupied separately, practical completion of the individual buildings can occur at different times (so that practical completion of any one building does not require practical completion of all the buildings).
(5) This section applies for the purposes of determining when completion of residential building work occurs for the purposes of any provision of this Act, the regulations or a contract of insurance under Part 6.

import pandas as pd
import json
import glob
import os
from datetime import datetime, timedelta
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.dates as mdates

def read\_csv(file\_path):
 df = pd.read\_csv(file\_path)
 return df
def extract\_rssi\_data(df):
 rssi\_data = {}
 for index, row in df.iterrows():
 epc\_data = row["combined\_epcs"]
 for epc, rssi\_values in epc\_data.items():
 if epc not in rssi\_data:
 rssi\_data[epc] = []
 rssi\_data[epc].append(rssi\_values)
 return rssi\_data
def count\_consistent\_and\_sparse\_tags(rssi\_data, total\_rows, threshold=0.5):
 consistent\_count = 0
 sparse\_count = 0
 consistent\_tags = []
 sparse\_tags = []
 total\_rssi\_consistent = [0, 0, 0, 0]
 total\_rssi\_sparse = [0, 0, 0, 0]
 n\_consistent = [0, 0, 0, 0]
 n\_sparse = [0, 0, 0, 0]

 for epc, rssi\_values\_list in rssi\_data.items():
 found\_count = sum(1 for rssi\_list in rssi\_values\_list if any(rssi != -1 for rssi in rssi\_list))
 found\_ratio = found\_count / total\_rows

 if found\_ratio >= threshold:
 consistent\_count += 1
 consistent\_tags.append(epc)
 for rssi\_list in rssi\_values\_list:
 for i in range(4):
 if rssi\_list[i] != -1:
 total\_rssi\_consistent[i] += rssi\_list[i]
 n\_consistent[i] += 1
 else:
 sparse\_count += 1
 sparse\_tags.append(epc)
 for rssi\_list in rssi\_values\_list:
 for i in range(4):
 if rssi\_list[i] != -1:
 total\_rssi\_sparse[i] += rssi\_list[i]
 n\_sparse[i] += 1

 avg\_rssi\_consistent = [0, 0, 0, 0]
 avg\_rssi\_sparse = [0, 0, 0, 0]

 for i in range(4):
 if n\_consistent[i] != 0:
 avg\_rssi\_consistent[i] = total\_rssi\_consistent[i] / n\_consistent[i]
 if n\_sparse[i] != 0:
 avg\_rssi\_sparse[i] = total\_rssi\_sparse[i] / n\_sparse[i]

 return consistent\_count, sparse\_count, consistent\_tags, sparse\_tags, avg\_rssi\_consistent, avg\_rssi\_sparse
def common\_tags(rssi\_data\_1, rssi\_data\_2):
 common\_epcs = set(rssi\_data\_1.keys()) & set(rssi\_data\_2.keys())
 return common\_epcs

def merge\_epcs(left, right):
 combined = left.copy()
 for epc, counts in right.items():
 if epc in combined:
 combined\_counts = combined[epc]
 merged\_counts = [
 (x + y) / 2 if (x != -1) and (y != -1) else x if x != -1 else y
 for x, y in zip(combined\_counts, counts)
 ]
 combined[epc] = merged\_counts
 else:
 combined[epc] = counts
 return combined
def combine\_rows\_within\_time\_range(df, max\_diff\_minutes=15):
 df['datetime'] = pd.to\_datetime(df['date'] + ' ' + df['time'])
 df.sort\_values(by='datetime', inplace=True)
 df.reset\_index(drop=True, inplace=True)

 combined\_rows = []
 i = 0
 while i < len(df):
 current\_row = df.iloc[i]
 combined\_epcs = current\_row['value']['stock\_ids']['epcs']

 j = i + 1
 while j < len(df) and df.iloc[j]['datetime'] - current\_row['datetime'] <= timedelta(minutes=max\_diff\_minutes):
 combined\_epcs = merge\_epcs(combined\_epcs, df.iloc[j]['value']['stock\_ids']['epcs'])
 j += 1

 combined\_rows.append({
 'datetime': current\_row['datetime'],
 'combined\_epcs': combined\_epcs
 })
 i = j

 return pd.DataFrame(combined\_rows)
def process\_csv\_files(path, cabinet\_pairs):
 cabinet\_dataframes = {}

 for cabinet\_pair in cabinet\_pairs:
 dataframes = []
 for file in glob.glob(os.path.join(path, f'\*{cabinet\_pair[0]}\*.csv')):
 df = pd.read\_csv(file)
 df['value'] = df['value'].str.replace("'", '"')
 df['value'] = df['value'].apply(json.loads)
 dataframes.append(df)

 for file in glob.glob(os.path.join(path, f'\*{cabinet\_pair[1]}\*.csv')):
 df = pd.read\_csv(file)
 df['value'] = df['value'].str.replace("'", '"')
 df['value'] = df['value'].apply(json.loads)
 dataframes.append(df)

 combined\_df = pd.concat(dataframes).sort\_values(['date', 'time']).reset\_index(drop=True)
 combined\_df = combine\_rows\_within\_time\_range(combined\_df)
 cabinet\_dataframes[cabinet\_pair] = combined\_df

 return cabinet\_dataframes

def calculate\_epc\_stats(df):
 total\_epcs = []
 for index, row in df.iterrows():
 epc\_data = row["combined\_epcs"]
 total\_epcs.append(len(epc\_data))

 avg\_total\_epcs = sum(total\_epcs) / len(total\_epcs)
 max\_total\_epcs = max(total\_epcs)
 min\_total\_epcs = min(total\_epcs)

 return avg\_total\_epcs, max\_total\_epcs, min\_total\_epcs

def find\_min\_total\_epc\_datetime(df):
 min\_total\_epcs = float('inf')
 min\_datetime = None
 for index, row in df.iterrows():
 epc\_data = row["combined\_epcs"]
 total\_epcs = len(epc\_data)

 if total\_epcs < min\_total\_epcs:
 min\_total\_epcs = total\_epcs
 min\_datetime = row['datetime']

 return min\_datetime, min\_total\_epcs

def main(result\_dfs):
 for cabinet\_pair, df in result\_dfs.items():
 # Extract the rssi data from the dataframe
 rssi\_data = extract\_rssi\_data(df)

 # Count the consistent and sparse tags in the rssi data
 total\_rows = len(df)
 consistent\_count, sparse\_count, consistent\_tags, sparse\_tags, avg\_rssi\_consistent, avg\_rssi\_sparse = count\_consistent\_and\_sparse\_tags(rssi\_data, total\_rows)
 avg\_total\_epcs, max\_total\_epcs, min\_total\_epcs = calculate\_epc\_stats(df)
 min\_datetime, min\_total\_epcs = find\_min\_total\_epc\_datetime(df)

 # Print the results
 print(f"Cabinet pair {cabinet\_pair}:")
 print(f"Consistent tags: {consistent\_count} EPCs consistently found, {sparse\_count} EPCs found sparsely")
 print(f"Consistent tags: {consistent\_tags}")
 print(f"Sparse tags: {sparse\_tags}")

 print(f"\nAverage RSSI values for consistent tags: {avg\_rssi\_consistent}")
 print(f"Average RSSI values for sparse tags: {avg\_rssi\_sparse}")
 print(f"Average total EPCs: {avg\_total\_epcs}")
 print(f"Maximum total EPCs: {max\_total\_epcs}")
 print(f"Minimum total EPCs: {min\_total\_epcs}")
 print(f"Minimum total EPCs: {min\_total\_epcs} at datetime: {min\_datetime}")

 print("\n")

def plot\_stock\_count(ax, df, cabinet\_pair):
 df['stock\_count'] = df['combined\_epcs'].apply(lambda x: len(x))
 min\_stock\_count = max(df['stock\_count'].min() - 5, 0)
 max\_stock\_count = df['stock\_count'].max() + 5

 ax.plot(df['datetime'], df['stock\_count'], marker='o')
 ax.set\_ylim(min\_stock\_count, max\_stock\_count)
 ax.set\_xlabel('Date and Time')
 ax.set\_ylabel('Stock Count')
 ax.set\_title(f'Stock Count for Cabinet Pair {cabinet\_pair}')
 ax.grid()

 ax.xaxis.set\_major\_formatter(mdates.DateFormatter('%H:%M'))

n\_cabinet\_pairs = len(result\_dfs)
fig, axes = plt.subplots(n\_cabinet\_pairs, 1, figsize=(10, 5 \* n\_cabinet\_pairs), sharex=True)

for i, (cabinet\_pair, df) in enumerate(result\_dfs.items()):
 plot\_stock\_count(axes[i], df, cabinet\_pair)

plt.tight\_layout()
plt.subplots\_adjust(hspace=0.5)
plt.show()

Make 3 multiple-choice reading comprehension questions based on the summary you made. Each question has 4 choices. Each question is followed by an answer. Give them 10 vocabulary words that will be helpful to complete their summary. Do not give them any writing example. No possible summary needed. They will only have 10 vocabulary words. Here's the news article:

Days after the International Criminal Court issued a warrant for his arrest, Russian President Vladimir Putin made a defiant visit to the city of Mariupol in his first trip to Ukrainian territory that Moscow illegally annexed in September.

Putin flew into the port city by helicopter and ‚Äútraveled around several districts of the city,‚Äù the Kremlin said in a statement Sunday, adding that he met several residents and went into one family's home after they invited him in.

Russia‚Äôs Deputy Prime Minister Marat Khusnullin said in a separate post on his Telegram channel that Putin ‚Äúpersonally inspected one of the residential areas, the building of the Philharmonic Society and assessed the roads, driving a car around the city.‚Äù
Ukraine ceded Mariupol to Russia in May, after a monthslong struggle that saw some of the most brutal Russian strikes of the conflict, including an attack on a theater that was serving as the city‚Äôs largest bomb shelter and a maternity hospital. Much of the strategic city still lies in ruins after relentless bombardment.

Having failed to take Ukraine‚Äôs capital Kyiv, it was Moscow's first major victory after it's invasion in February.

But by then the city had become a worldwide symbol of defiance after small group of outgunned Ukrainian fighters held out for 83 days in the sprawling Azovstal steelworks in the east of the city, in one of the war‚Äôs longest and bloodiest battles. The fighters dogged defense tied down Russian forces and held up their eastern offensive.

An estimated 100,000 people remained in the city after its capture out of a pre-war population of 450,000.

Khusnullin said Sunday he had reported to Putin on ‚Äúthe construction of new housing and infrastructure, the improvement of territories, road construction and economic development.‚Äù

In a separate interview with the state-owned news agency RIA Novosti, he said that ‚Äúpeople began to return actively‚Äù to the city ‚Äúwhen they saw that the restoration was going on.‚Äù

NBC News could not verify this claim.

It was Putin‚Äôs second unannounced trip of the weekend to Russian-occupied areas of Ukraine. He also traveled to nearby Crimea to mark the ninth anniversary of the Black Sea Peninsula‚Äôs annexation from Ukraine.

While Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has made a number of trips to battlefields to boost soldier morale, Putin has mainly remained inside the Kremlin throughout the year-long conflict, and his visit to Mariupol was the closest he has been to the front lines since the invasion.

Russia annexed Crimea from Ukraine in 2014, a move that most of the world denounced as illegal. Following referendums that Kyiv and the West described as a sham in September, Moscow claimed four regions in Ukraine‚Äôs south and east as Russian territory, including Donetsk, where Mariupol is situated. The Kremlin statement said that Putin had also met with the top command of his military operation in Ukraine, including Chief of the General Staff Valery Gerasimov, who is in charge of the war, at the Rostov-on-Don command post in southern Russia.

While Putin has largely been exempt from complaints, some of Moscow‚Äôs pro-war agitators have seen the nonappearance of senior ministers to the battlefields as evidence they are not strong enough on Ukraine.

His visits came a day after the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for the Russian leader, accusing him of committing the ‚Äúwar crime‚Äù of overseeing the unlawful abduction and deportation of children from Ukraine to Russia.

It said there were reasonable grounds to believe that Putin bore individual responsibility for the crimes, and that he had failed to exercise proper control over subordinates who committed the acts.

Moscow has consistently denied allegations of war crimes, describing them as a ‚Äúfantasy‚Äù aimed at discrediting Russia. Putin‚Äôs press secretary Dmitry Peskov rejected the court‚Äôs findings. ‚ÄúWe do not recognize this court, we do not recognize the jurisdiction of this court. This is how we treat this,‚Äù he said in a Telegram post Friday.
However, ‚ÄúRussia can‚Äôt present this as traveling ‚Äòabroad‚Äô in defiance of the ICC,‚Äù according to Keir Giles, a senior consulting fellow on Russia and Eurasia at the London think tank Chatham House.

‚ÄúCrimea and Mariupol are in Ukraine, just temporarily occupied by Russian troops, but to admit that fact would run counter to Moscow‚Äôs whole narrative that they should be treated as belonging to Russia,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúAdmitting that a day trip to Mariupol is a visit to a foreign country would also be an admission that Russia has illegally occupied its neighbor,‚Äù he added.

Elsewhere, Yevgeny Prigozhin, a billionaire oligarch who runs the private army the Wagner Group said Saturday that he plans to recruit 30,000 new fighters by mid-May.

‚ÄúWe have days when we‚Äôre recruiting up to 1200 people a day. On average, the number‚Äôs oscillating between 500-800 [people] and there‚Äôs currently a spike in growth,‚Äù Prighozin said in a statement posted to the Russian social media site VK on Saturday.

The Wagner group previously recruited convicts from Russian prisons but said it had stopped in January. Here's another personal statement that's considered excellent for college admissions. Can you highlight multiple reasons why it worked well?

This is what someone else had to say about this essay and why it worked well, can you summarize this person's opinion in bullet points?

Opinion on why this essay worked well:
Get clear on the story you‚Äôre telling. Debate? Political organizing? Musical theater? Protest music? This writer probably had a lot more to say about all of those experiences. But we don‚Äôt get the whole backstory about her journey toward musical theater. Why? Because she‚Äôs clear on what this story is about (she may have even written a logline to get that clarity‚Ä¶). We don‚Äôt need a lot of context about her decision ‚Äúnot to participate in the musical‚Äù because this essay isn‚Äôt about her experiences with musical theater; it‚Äôs about her forging a new identity by combining seemingly disparate interests (e.g., music and political advocacy). Telling us every musical she‚Äôs ever been in won‚Äôt help us ‚Äúget‚Äù what she‚Äôs saying in this essay (and she has the activities list to tell us that‚Ä¶). Instead, she shows us only the details relevant to her trying to balance a love of music with her newfound interests: she decides ‚Äúnot to participate in the musical,‚Äù and she ‚Äúhalts voice and piano lessons.‚Äù

Bridge the gap (between paragraphs). Stronger essays have paragraphs with clear relationships to one another. This writer uses various phrases to achieve that clarity. When she starts paragraph four with ‚Äúthis introduction,‚Äù you understand that she‚Äôs referring to her ‚Äúsongs about the Syrian Refugee Crisis‚Äù from the end of paragraph three. Similarly, she resolves the problem of her ‚Äúlosing touch‚Äù with music at the end of paragraph two by beginning paragraph three by stating she found a ‚Äúnew way of being‚Ä¶‚Äù She‚Äôs using those key moments of transition to tell her readers: hey, I‚Äôm going somewhere with all these ideas, you can trust me.

You don‚Äôt have to have all the answers. When the writer tells us that she sang ‚ÄúAmazing Grace‚Äù to honor someone in her community who died by suicide, she gets vulnerable‚Äîshe says that she still doesn't ‚Äúfully understand‚Äù the effects of that moment. In admitting that she‚Äôs still coming to terms with that experience, she comes off as a mature, reasoned person who thinks deeply about lived experience. No one reading your essay is going to expect you to have fully processed every difficult experience you‚Äôve ever had in your life. That would be outrageous. What they will appreciate seeing, though, is that you‚Äôve reflected deeply on lived experiences. Sometimes reflection yields answers. Sometimes it just yields more questions. Either is okay‚Äîjust don‚Äôt feel like you need to have everything figured out to write about it (or that you need to pretend like you do).

Basic Parameters
Aspect Ratios
--aspect, or --ar Change the aspect ratio of a generation.
Chaos
--chaos Change how varied the results will be. Higher values produce more unusual and unexpected generations.
No
--no Negative prompting, --no plants would try to remove plants from the image.
Quality
--quality <.25, .5, 1, or 2>, or --q <.25, .5, 1, or 2> How much rendering quality time you want to spend. The default value is 1. Higher values cost
more and lower values cost less.
Seed
--seed The Midjourney bot uses a seed number to create a field of visual noise, like television static, as a
starting point to generate the initial image grids. Seed numbers are generated randomly for each image but can be specified with the --seed or
--sameseed parameter. Using the same seed number and prompt will produce similar ending images.
Stop
--stop Use the --stop parameter to finish a Job partway through the process. Stopping a Job at an earlier percentage
can create blurrier, less detailed results.
Style
--style <4a, 4b or 4c> Switch between versions of the Midjourney Model Version 4
Stylize
--stylize , or --s parameter influences how strongly Midjourney's default aesthetic style is applied to Jobs.
Uplight
--uplight Use an alternative "light" upscaler when selecting the U buttons. The results are closer to the original grid image. The upscaled image is
less detailed and smoother.
Upbeta
--upbeta Use an alternative beta upscaler when selecting the U buttons. The results are closer to the original grid image. The upscaled image has
significantly fewer added details. Default Values (Model Version 5)

The three mission-based institutional priorities for Jayhawks Rising are ‚ÄúStudent Success‚Äù, ‚ÄúHealthy and Vibrant Communities‚Äù, and ‚ÄúResearch and Discovery‚Äù. Thirteen objectives were identified under the three priorities. Each objective has co-leaders ‚Äì deans and vice provosts with responsibilities tied to the objective ‚Äì who will guide our efforts, involve stakeholders and lead implementation of strategies and action steps and help ensure continuous progress and success. Here is an outline of the thirteen objectives:
STUDENT SUCCESS
¬∑ Increase Enrollment: We aim to expand our diverse community of ambitious and talented students, increasing access to a world class education for more first time freshman, new transfers, returning and graduate students. We will expand the reach of KU programming to connect to Jayhawks near and far, through on campus courses, around the nation in virtual formats, and across the globe.
¬∑ Assure Retention and Completion Through Student Engagement and Satisfaction: While student presence, persistence, and performance are indicators of a satisfied student population, it is also meaningful to assess and monitor student engagement and satisfaction directly. Engaged and satisfied students are more likely to retain, ultimately complete, and pass on the message that KU is a fantastic choice for higher education.
¬∑ Support Student Long-Term Success by Improving Placement & Reducing Debt: While earning a degree from KU is part of why students attend KU, what they do with that degree is also of great importance. Additionally, the cost of higher education remains prominent in students‚Äô minds when selecting a higher education institution.
¬∑ Assure Quality of Academic Programs: No matter the domain, Jayhawks aspire for quality. When a student comes to KU, we must provide them with an excellent academic experience. By constantly raising the bar and meeting new challenges, we will ensure that our students receive an education that goes beyond the standard.
HEALTHY & VIBRANT COMMUNITIES
¬∑ Strengthen Service to Local and Global Communities: Strengthening our service to local and global communities provides opportunities for our talented staff, faculty, and students to impact expansive programs near and far from KU. The volume and quality of services provided reflects our aspiration to impact communities across the world.
¬∑ Improve Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging: With the ever-changing landscape of our country, and world, it is important to the University of Kansas that we make changes that create an environment of fairness, respect, and belonging. All students, staff, and faculty should have the greatest opportunities to meet their academic and professional goals. KU will examine and expand programs in order to meet our aspirations.
¬∑ Improve Health and Wellness: There is more to academic success than grades and graduation. At the University of Kansas, we want all our Jayhawks to have the highest quality of life. In addition to physical health and wellness, we will focus on providing an environment where students, staff, and faculty are supported with adequate benefits and resources, are safe on campus, and have their basic needs met.
RESEARCH AND DISCOVERY
¬∑ Grow KU Research: Research at KU has an acclaimed record of discovery and innovation at the local, regional, national, and global level. Growing KU research across the university allows us to continue to solve problems, ask new questions, inform leaders and policy makers, and inspire others.
¬∑ Recruit, Retain and Recognize Top Researchers: Central to a robust and impactful research enterprise are exceptional humans. Attracting highly productive and innovative researchers enhances KU‚Äôs ability to conduct research that advances society. Retaining these gifted individuals requires KU to build a research support system that matches their ambitions to make discoveries that change the world and gain recognition for their work. Through financial and administrative support, KU will recruit, retain and recognize researchers working at the highest level, building a research enterprise that is impactful to the state, nation and beyond.
¬∑ Expand the Impact of KU Research in Kansas and Beyond: The University of Kansas aims to be an exceptional learning community that lifts each other, contributes to the wider scholarly enterprise and advances society. To measure and expand the impact of our research, KU focuses on research contributions in three key areas: academia; projects focused on core communities in our home state and beyond; involvement of students in research and their training to become future researchers.
¬∑ Promote Innovation and Entrepreneurship: KU research impacts society in ways that go way beyond contributing to the more traditional idea of academic knowledge. Notably, KU research translates into inventions, products and business startups that provide health, economic, education and other benefits for society.

Medium Neutral Citation: Tan v Champion Homes Sales Pty Ltd [2021] NSWCATAP 236
Hearing dates: 24 May 2021
Date of orders: 6 August 2021
Decision date: 06 August 2021
Jurisdiction: Appeal Panel
Before: D Cowdroy AO QC ADCJ, Principal Member
D Robertson, Senior Member
Decision: 
(1) Leave to appeal is refused.

(2) The appeal is dismissed.

Catchwords: 
BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION ‚Äì No issue of principle REASONS FOR DECISION

By a decision published on 12 February 2021, the Tribunal ordered the appellants, Hua Hong Tan, Lui Sing Ling and Matthew Jin Lin to pay the respondent, Champion Homes Sales Pty Ltd, the sum of $41,707.09, and dismissed an application brought by the appellants.

The appellants appeal and seek leave to appeal against that decision.

The appellants are the owners of a property at Kensington, New South Wales. The appellants contracted in writing with the respondent on 21 April 2018 to construct a duplex on the appellants‚Äô property with a contract price of $759,980. We will refer to the appellants as the owners and the respondents as the builder.

The owners had previously paid a tender fee of $25,000 in relation to a tender dated 2 February 2018 issued by the builder, bringing the total price to $784,980.

Under the contract, the tender price was fixed provided that building work commenced by 18 January 2019, which was 350 days from the tender date. Clause 44.2 of the building contract provided that the builder was to commence building works within 20 working days after the owner satisfied a number of specified requirements including ‚Äúcompletion by the owner of demolition of existing dwelling on site to enable the builder to commence building works‚Äù. If work did not commence by 18 January 2019, the builder was entitled to a contract price adjustment in the amount of $18,999.50.

The building work did not commence before 18 January 2019. It appears that demolition, which was to be carried out by the owners, had not even commenced by 18 January 2019.

The builder filed proceedings HB 20/13125 on 17 March 2020 claiming what was said to be moneys owing in respect of the contract, comprising the contract price adjustment of $18,999.50, variation 13 for traffic management costs of $10,317.30 and variation 14 of $12,390.29 for structural steel frames.

The owners filed application HB 20/20818 on 12 May 2020 by which they sought an order that they were not liable to pay the contract price adjustment of $18,999.50 and also sought compensation of $50,000 for alleged defective works plus damages for delay.

The owners also resisted liability for variations 13 and 14 as excessive, including on the basis that the builder had not efficiently organised deliveries so as to minimise the traffic control charge, and on the basis that the variation claims were not properly verified or authorised.

By their Notice of Appeal the owners challenged the Tribunal‚Äôs findings in relation to each of:

The contract price adjustment;

The variation relating to traffic management costs;

The variation for structural steel frames; and

The Tribunal‚Äôs failure to award the owners compensation in respect of damage to the footpath allegedly caused by the builder.

At the hearing of the appeal Mr Vardas, the builder‚Äôs business manager, conceded that the builder had agreed, in the course of the hearing at first instance, that the builder would credit the owners with the amount of $2,238.50 in respect of the footpath. As that was the amount the owners had sought, it is apparent that that issue has been resolved without intervention by the Tribunal and it is not necessary to make any orders in that regard.

Working Thesis: Living a life of purpose and fulfillment makes happiness easier to obtain, however, there must be a balance between achieving goals and relieving stress. 
Topic Sentence one: Having a grateful heart for the opportunities and blessings one receives in life plays a crucial role in happiness. 
‚Ä¢ People often become depressed because they forget to be thankful for the things they do have and shift their focus more on the things they don‚Äôt thinking that will make them happy. (Achor)
‚Ä¢ If people put themselves in the shoes of the less fortunate, they can learn to appreciate the little things, for as Sutherland elaborates, perspective is everything in deeming human happiness. (Sutherland)

Topic Sentence Two: The state of happiness is a constant effort of free choice and daily active progression towards keeping the foundation of happiness from becoming stagnant or freezing. 
‚Ä¢ Having too much on one‚Äôs plate can deter them from happiness because there too much to simply keep up with that it may provoke unwanted stress and tension in their lives. (Graham)
‚Ä¢ Happiness and stagnation do not go hand in hand. Too much inactivity in one‚Äôs life will affect their fulfillment and purpose, consequently, they will look for quick feelings of pleasure rather than putting in effort for the longevity feeling of happiness. (Matthieu)
-USE ANALOGY: When a dog finds unfulfillment in life, he will search for it by digging holes. Seeking quick pleasurable joy. Just like people will begin to dig voids in their life when there is unfulfillment in one‚Äôs life.
‚Ä¢ It is imperative to know balance. PLAY, BUT WORK HARDER 

Topic Sentence Three: The state of happiness is not always at the finish line; however, it is always right beside you.
‚Ä¢ Beware of the role your consciousness plays within the state of happiness
‚Ä¢ Constantly stressing about the things, you cannot change will be detrimental towards one‚Äôs own state of happiness 
‚Ä¢ Happiness is not some unreachable goal or unmundane ambition that only the one percent can attain. 
‚Ä¢ Sometimes less is more (Graham)

Topic Sentence Four: One must first seek happiness within themselves before expecting for something external to grant them happiness. 
‚Ä¢ Having control of your life will grant you serenity and peace, therefore giving way to happiness. (Sutherland)
‚Ä¢ Developing ways of synthesizing your own happiness can have a profound effect on keeping oneself happiness
‚Ä¢ Synthetic happiness- creating one‚Äôs own happiness from within (choosing to be happy just because you can) (Gilbert)
‚Ä¢ Natural Happiness can be a way of motivating yourself to further oneself into happiness with transcendence. (Gilbert)

Creating Engaging E-Learning Resources for Grade 12 Teacher Education.

Overview:

The project based lesson plan will have students create an interactive e-learning activity or resource for a specific group in the Teacher Education subject area. The goal of this lesson is to develop a structured and engaging learning experience that can be used by the target group.

Students will be able to:

1. Students will be able to create a subject-oriented interactive learning resource.
2. Students will be able to develop a structured and interactive e-learning activity or resource for a specific group in their subject specialism.
3. Students will be able to identify the needs of the target group and design a resource that meets those needs.
4. Students will be able to evaluate the effectiveness of their e-learning activity or resource. 
5. Students will be able to use feedback from peers and instructors to refine their e-learning resources.

Lesson Plan:

Project Idea: 
Students will be tasked with creating an engaging e-learning resource for Grade 12 Teacher Education. They will need to research and explore what makes an effective e-learning resource and use this knowledge to create their own. 

Exploration: 
The teacher will lead the students in a discussion about what makes an effective e-learning resource, covering topics such as visuals, audio, interactivity, relevance, and accuracy. The teacher may also provide some examples of good e-learning resources for the students to analyze. 

Brainstorm and Plan: 
The students will then brainstorm ideas for their own e-learning resource and create a plan outlining the content, structure, visuals, audio, interactivity etc. that they plan to include in their resource. They should also identify any potential challenges or issues that may arise during the creation process. 

Create: 
The students will then use their plan to create their own e-learning resource using technology tools of their choice (e.g., PowerPoint, Adobe Creative Suite). They should be encouraged to experiment with different media types and technologies to make their resource as engaging as possible. 

Feedback and Iterate: 
Once the students have finished creating their resources they will present them to the class for feedback and critique. The teacher can then help guide the students in making improvements or changes based on the feedback they received from peers. This process can be repeated multiple times until the students are satisfied with the final product. 

Reflection: Finally, the teacher should lead a class discussion where each student reflects on what they learned during this project-based lesson and how it has helped them develop skills related to creating effective e-learning resources.

WUDHU [ABLUTION]

1. The person making wudhu should face the qiblah and sit on an elevated place so that the water does not splash on him.

2. When commencing wudhu, Bismillahir Rahm√¢nir Raheem should be recited.

3. First of all, the hands should be washed up to the wrists three times.

4. Thereafter, rinse the mouth three times and use a misw√¢k.

38

5. If there is no misw√¢k, a thick cloth or even the fore-finger could be used so that all the dirt is removed.

6. If the person is not fasting, he should gargle the mouth thoroughly. However, if he is fasting, he should not gargle thoroughly because there is a possibility that water will go down the throat.

7. Thereafter, rinse the nose three times and clean it with the left hand. However, the fasting person should not allow the water to go beyond the soft-bone of the nose.

8. Wash the face three times: from the hair-line till below the chin, and from one ear-lobe to the other. Water must reach all these places. Water must also reach below the eye brows - no place should remain dry.

9. Wash the right hand up to and including the elbows.

10. Thereafter wash the left hand up to and including the elbows.

11. Make khil√¢l of the fingers. That is, pass the fingers of one hand through the fingers of the other hand.

12. If there is a ring or any such jewellery on the fingers, it should be removed so that no part is left dry.

13. Thereafter make masah of the head (passing wet hands over the head).

14. Make masah of the ears by inserting the forefingers into the ears and making masah of the back of the ear-lobes with the thumb of each hand.

15. Make masah of the neck with the back of the fingers of both hands. However, masah of the fore-neck/throat should not be made as this is prohibited.

16. Fresh water need not be used for making masah of the ears. Whatever water is left over after making masah of the head will be sufficient.

17. Thereafter wash the right foot up to and including the ankles. Do the same for the left foot.

Make khil√¢l of the toes of the feet with the little finger of the left hand. When making khil√¢l, commence with the little toe of the right foot and end with the little toe of the left foot.

This is the correct method of performing wudhu. However, there are certain acts, which if even a part is left out or not completed, then the wudhu will be regarded as incomplete. In fact, it will be as if wudhu was not performed at all. Such acts are called fardh. There are other acts, which if left out, the wudhu will be regarded as complete. Carrying out these acts will entail reward (thaw√¢b) and these have been emphasised in the Shariah. It is a sin to leave out such acts unnecessarily. Such acts are called Sunnats. There are other acts, which if carried out entail reward, and if left out, entail no sin. Neither have they been emphasised in the Shariah. Such acts are called mustahab.

Fardh (compulsory) acts of wudhu

There are four fardh acts in wudhu:-

1. To wash the entire face once.

2. To wash both hands up to and including the elbows once.

3. To make masah of one-quarter of the head once.

4. To wash both feet up to and including the ankles once.

39

These are the fardh acts of wudhu. Even if one of these acts is left out, or even if a place equal to a hair's breadth is left dry, wudhu will not be complete.

Sunnah acts of wudhu

1. To say Bismillahir Rahm√¢nir Raheem.

2. To wash both hands up to the wrists.

3. To rinse the mouth.

4. To wash the nose.

5. To use misw√¢k.

6. To make masah of the entire head.

7. To wash each part three times.

8. To make masah of the ears.

9. To make khil√¢l of the fingers and toes.

Apart from this, the balance of the acts are mustahab.

1. Once the four fardh acts of wudhu are carried out, wudhu will be regarded as complete, irrespective of whether one intended to make wudhu or not, eg.: (a) at the time of bathing, one pours water on the entire body, or (b) falls into a well, or river , or (c) stands in the rain. In all these conditions, if the limbs of wudhu get wet, wudhu will be regarded as complete.

However, one will not obtain the reward (thaw√¢b) of wudhu.

2. Sunnah is to make wudhu exactly as has been mentioned above. But if anyone alters or reverses the procedure of wudhu, eg. by washing the feet first, then making masah, and then washing the hands, and thereafter washing the face, or alters the procedure in any other way -

then wudhu will still be regarded as complete. However, it will not be considered to be in accordance with the sunnah, and there is always the fear of having sinned.

3. Similarly, if the left hand or the left foot is washed first, wudhu will be completed, but it will be contrary to being mustahab.

4. After washing one part, one should not delay in washing the next part to such an extent that the first part gets dry. Instead, he should wash the next part as quickly as possible. If, after washing the second part, the first part gets dry, then wudhu will be regarded as complete, but it will be contrary to the sunnah.

5. It is also sunnah to pass the hand on the part that is being washed so that no place is left dry.

6. It is better and mustahab to prepare for wudhu and sal√¢t well before the time.

7. As long as there is no genuine excuse, one should perform wudhu with one's very own hands and should not seek assistance from someone else.

8. While making wudhu, worldly talk should be avoided. Instead, Bismillah and the kalimah should be read on washing each and every part.

9. No matter how freely water may be available, it should not be wasted. Even if one is at the sea-shore, one should not use more than necessary. At the same time, one should not use so little water that one has problems in washing the parts thoroughly.

10. The parts should not be washed more than three times.

40

11. . When washing the face, water should not be splashed with great force, nor should one splash water by making hissing sounds.

12. One should not close one's eyes and mouth very tightly. All these things are makruh and prohibited. The reason for this is that if the mouth and eyes are shut so tightly to the extent that the lips or eye lashes remain dry, then the wudhu will not be regarded as complete.

13. If rings, bangles, bracelets, etc. are so loose that water will reach under them without having to remove them, it will still be mustahab to remove them. If they are so tight that there is a possibility of water not reaching under them, then it will be necessary and wajib to remove them. A similar rule applies to the nose ring: that is, if it is loose, then it will be mustahab to move it, and if it is tight, then while one is washing the face it will be wajib to move it around so that water reaches everywhere.

14. If some dough or similar substance got stuck under the nails and got dried, and water did not reach there, the wudhu will not be complete. If one sees the flour and realizes that water did not reach there, then water should be poured over it. However, if sal√¢t was performed prior to pouring the water, it will be necessary to repeat the sal√¢t.

15. If one has applied tinsel or some other decorative paint on the forehead and does not wash it thoroughly, but just pours water over it, then wudhu will not be completed. It should be removed before washing the face.

16. After having performed the wudhu, Surah al-Qadr should be recited.

Thereafter the following dua should be recited:

["O Allah! Make me of the repentants, and make me of the purified, and include me among Your pious servants."]

17. After having performed the wudhu, it is preferable to read two rak√¢ts of nafl sal√¢t. This sal√¢t is called Tahiyyatul wudhu. Great reward and merit has been mentioned in the Hadith in regard to this sal√¢t.

18. If one had made wudhu for a particular sal√¢t, and thereafter the next sal√¢t time entered without the wudhu having broken, then it will be permissible to read sal√¢t with that same wudhu.

However, if the person repeats the wudhu, he will be greatly rewarded.

19. Once wudhu has been made and has not broken as yet, then as long as no act of worship (ib√¢dat) has been performed with that wudhu, it will be makruh to make a new wudhu. Based on this, if a person makes wudhu while bathing, then he should read his sal√¢t with that same wudhu. Without that wudhu breaking, he should not make a new wudhu. However, if a person has read even just two rak√¢ts of sal√¢t with that first wudhu, then there will be no problem in making a second wudhu. In fact, there is reward in making a second wudhu.

20. If someone's hands or feet are cracked and he filled them with wax, an ointment, or some other medicine (and he fears some harm by removing it) then his wudhu will be regarded as complete if he just poured water over it without having removed the medicine.

21. If water did not reach the heels or some other place while making wudhu, and only after completing the wudhu one realized that a particular place is dry, it will not be sufficient to merely pass the hand over that place. Instead, water will have to be poured over it.

22. If there is a sore or some other wound on the hands, feet, etc. and one fears that it would be harmful to pour water over it, then water should not be poured. Instead, the wet hand should 41

be passed over the wound. This is called masah. If this is harmful, masah should not be made and that place should be left out.

23. If a wound has been bandaged and it will be harmful to open the bandage and make masah over the wound, or it will be difficult and painful to open the bandage, then in both cases it will be permissible to make masah on the bandage. But if this is not the case, the bandage will have to be removed and masah will have to be made on the wound.

24. If the wound is not under the entire bandage, then after opening the bandage, that portion which is not wounded should be washed if possible. However, if it is not possible to open the bandage, masah should be made on both the portions- the wounded and the unwounded portions.

25. In case of a fracture where splints and pads are applied, the above directions will apply. That is, as long as the splints cannot be opened, it will be sufficient to make masah over it. The same rule will apply to plasters - that is, if masah cannot be made on the wound, the plaster should be removed and masah should be made on the gauze. But if there is no one to help in opening and closing the plaster, then it will be sufficient to make masah on the plaster itself.

26. In the case of bandages, splints, plasters, etc. it is preferable to make masah on the entire covering. If this is not possible, then it will be permissible to make masah on more than half of the covering. However, it is not permissible to suffice with masah on half or less of the covering.

27. If after performing masah, the bandage, plaster, etc., opens up and one sees that the wound has not healed as yet, then it should be re-tied and the previous masah will suffice. However, if the wound has healed and there is no need to bandage it again, then the masah will be broken. That portion should be washed and sal√¢t performed. There is no need to repeat the entire wudhu.

28. Khil√¢l [passing of wet fingers] of the beard should be made three times after having washed the face. Khil√¢l should not be made more than three times.

29. It is fardh to wash the chin as long as there is no hair of the beard on it, or if there is, it is so little that the skin can be seen.

30. It is fardh to wash that part of the lips which can be seen after the lips are closed.

31. If the hair of the beard, moustache and eyebrows is so thick that the skin cannot be seen, then it is not fardh to wash that skin which is hidden. That hair is actually in place of the skin. To pour water over it is sufficient.

32. If the hair of the eyebrows, beard, or moustache is so thick that the skin cannot be seen, then in such a case it is wajib to wash that hair which falls within the boundaries of the face. It is not wajib to wash the hair that is beyond the boundaries of the face.

33. If a person's piles come out, his wudhu will break irrespective of whether it went back inside on its own, or by pushing it back with a stick, a cloth, or his hand.

34. If semen comes out without any desire, wudhu will break. For example, a person carried a very heavy weight, or jumped from an elevated place and due to this shock semen came out without any desire.

35. If there is some defect in one's senses, but this defect does not reach the stage of insanity or unconsciousness, his wudhu will not break.

36. If a person sleeps away and laughs (in his sleep) while in sal√¢t, his wudhu will not break.

37. By laughing in a janaza sal√¢t or in a sajdah til√¢wat wudhu will not break irrespective of whether the person is mature or immature.

AGvisorPRO's Go-To Market Strategy:
Multichannel Marketing:
We have been successful in digital marketing advertisement through several channels. Our most successful approach to date is influencer marketing through agriculture podcasts and social media. We have also been able to generate organic reach.
Once a user has found and loves our platform, we have the right mechanism in place to generate word of mouth referrals and referral loops within the platform. 

Industry Network Partners:
Ag retail needs to improve their online grower experience (McKinsey & Co., April 26, 2021). Companies and associations bring their network of members/employees onto the AGvisorPRO platform in a private, branded channel. This provides a home for the client to communicate internally, evangelise their products, and provide better customer service. AGvisorPRO generates an expanded user base in the overarching AGvisorPRO network. Ex-CEO of Nutrien, Mike Frank said: ‚ÄúOur best sales agronomists are at capacity doing it the old way. With these digital tools, they‚Äôre able to increase the number of acres that they can serve by probably 25% to 40%.‚Äù AGvisorPRO allows representatives to reach growers more efficiently, in a more convenient way. We handle transactions, reducing administrative work, and providing an eCommerce experience within a digital platform farmers want to use (Upstream Ag Insights, Aug 15, 2021).

We have signed Commercial Pilot Agreements, valued up to $100k each, with Farmers Mutual Hail and Young‚Äôs Equipment, and have more in various stages of negotiation. 

Strategic Partnerships:
We are partnered with Saskatchewan Agriculture, Results Driven Agriculture Research (RDAR - Alberta Ag), Manitoba Agriculture Service Corp, Agriculture Financial Service Corp, Nevonex by Bosch. AGvisorPRO is embedded in the xarvio (BASF) SCOUTING app. We are also partnering with the North American Equipment Dealers Association, Solvi.ag, and Farmers Business Network.

Expansion Roadmap:
2021-2022 North America
2025 English Speaking with Seed Round, expanding SAM to 2.9M farmers (SOM $322M).
2026 English + Latin America, Series A, SAM 17.9M farmers, >$1B SOM
2027 Global, IPO, SAM 570M farmers, >$1B SOM

AGvisorPRO Team:
Our team has a track record of growing and creating jobs (>300), export growth, and going from $0 to $50M in revenue. We have a strong board of directors and team leaders who have gone through 5 exits, totalling over $700M. Our development and product teams go from discovery to deployment in rapid iterations. They focus only on developing high impact or highly leverageable features that will be valuable for our users and valuable for our business. 

Robert Saik is the founder and CEO with more than 40 years as a Professional Agrologist and entrepreneur. He has global experience in the field of agricultural technology integration. He founded The Agri-Trend/Agri-Data Group of Companies which was acquired by Trimble, and was CEO of DOT Technology Corp through its sale to Raven Industries. 
Patrick Walther is the co-founder and COO with a deep understanding of agricultural systems. MSc. Agronomy and On-Farm Research. Brock Moir, CPO, has experience building and leading products and projects that leverage data science, and machine intelligence, across multiple industries, including building energy, construction, technology, and agriculture. 
Norm Janssen, Business Development Leader: Former Investment Attraction Manager for Alberta Ag & Forestry, leading various teams that brought billions of investment dollars into Alberta.
Joe Middione, Business Development Leader: Former COO of Agrian by TELUS, General Manager at UAP West, and Strategic Business Manager with Generic Crop Science. Joe had 3 private exits in excess of $600M. 

AGvisorPRO Metrics:
In the early days of building a market network, we must prioritise user acquisition over revenue generation. 

700+ industry leading experts with solutions in broad acre crops, livestock, equipment, vertical farming, and more.
There are 40+ businesses who agreed to pay $500/month subscription (paused for feature testing). 
We have active users in 52+ states and provinces across North America. Our Monthly Active Users is growing by 23% month-over-month. At our current rate, we will have 8000 active users in 18 months, with >900 questions and >1500 answers. A spend of $12.50 per user would give us $1M ARR, making AGvisorPRO default alive by 2024.
38% of our users responded that they would be very disappointed if AGvisorPRO ceased to exist. 
We reduced churn by 66% in the last 6 months. 
We mastered digital marketing in the ag sector (John Deere Financial is one of our clients).

This module contains many simple and atomic utils that can be used in Kotlin backend projects.
Feel free to cherry-pick the one you need for your project.

## Errors lib

### Introduction
This library contains base classes and interfaces for representing application errors.
The idea is to use objects and return values to represent errors instead of exceptions.
This library is based on [arrow-kt](https://arrow-kt.io/): it uses extensively the `arrow.core.Either` datatype (and potentially other utils from arrow).

Functions should return an `Either` whose left side is an error object and whose right side is the result of the function.
Callers of those function can then decide to handle the error or not.

Errors with `Either` offer the same error handling capabilities as exceptions:
- Catching / recovering from errors can be done by using the `handleError` or `handleErrorWith` operators
- Rethrowing / raising a different error can be done with the `mapLeft` operator
- Propagating errors can be done by simply returning the `Either` value

The benefits are multiple:
- Error types are explicit, without the need for complicated verbose type signatures, like with checked exceptions
- Errors can be handled as values, without the need for `try` / `catch` blocks
- Error handling is more explicit: each function error case need to be handled or propagated.
 With exceptions, error propagation is implicit and can lead to unexpected behavior

Other modules in this repository depend on this base error abstraction to provide a consistent error handling mechanism.

### Usage
The core of this module is the `ApplicationError` interface. All user defined errors should inherit from this interface.
There are multiple subtypes of `ApplicationError`:
- `RetryableApplicationError` => errors that can be retried
- `NonRetryableApplicationError` => errors that cannot / shouldn't be retried.
 This subtype further specialises in more types.
 Other libraries may decide to present these errors types differently to the user.
 - `NotFoundError` => errors that indicate that a resource was not found
 - `ConflictError` => errors that indicate that a resource already exists / would result in a conflict
 - `InvalidInputError` => errors that indicate that the input is invalid

To define a new type of error, simply create a new class that inherits from one of the above subtypes.
```kotlin
data class FluxCapacitorOverloadedError(
 override val message: String = "Flux Capacitor overloaded",
 override val meta: Map = emptyMap(),
 override val cause: Throwable? = null,
) : RetryableApplicationError
```

For convenience, some helper classes are available to easily create new types of errors without having to redeclare all the fields:
```kotlin
// without dynamic fields
object FluxCapacitorOverloadedError : DefaultRetryableApplicationError(message = "Flux Capacitor overloaded")

// with dynamic fields
data class FluxCapacitorOverloadedError(
 val capacitorId: Long,
) : DefaultRetryableApplicationError(
 message = "Flux Capacitor $capacitorId overloaded",
 meta = mapOf("capacitorId" to capacitorId),
)
```

To signify that a method can return an error, simply return an `Either` whose left side is an `ApplicationError`
and whose right side is the result of the function.
You could use the convenient `ErrorOr`, which is a typealias for `Either`.
```kotlin
fun turnOnFluxCapacitor(capacitorId: Long): ErrorOr {
 if (isOverloaded(capacitorId)) {
 return FluxCapacitorOverloadedError(capacitorId).left()
 }
 // do stuff
 return FluxCapacitor(capacitorId).right()

}
```

To bridge the gap between functional and imperative world, it is sometimes mandatory to use exceptions to signal errors to the framework with use.
This is for example the case with Spring Transactional methods, or with jvm-kit event listeners.

For that reason, this lib exposes a very convenient util call `orThrow` that can be called on an instance of `ErrorOr`.
This util will (by default) throw an `ApplicationException` if the `ErrorOr` is a `Left` and return the value if it is a `Right`.
The `ApplicationException` extends `RuntimeException` and will contain the underlying error object.
If the error object had a cause, the `ApplicationException` will have its cause set to the original error cause.

```kotlin
val fluxCapacitor: FluxCapacitor = turnOnFluxCapacitor(capacitorId).orThrow()
```

## Well Known Tiny types
### Overview
This library provides a collection of Kotlin utilities for managing and validating various data types within the Glovo ecosystem.
It includes several value classes and error classes to handle different types of input, such as city codes, country codes, currency codes, and time zones.
Those classes are represented as inline value classes (aka Tiny Types),
which means that they are lightweight and do not incur any runtime overhead (aka Zero Cost Abstraction).

### Features
- Encapsulates various data validation and parsing within value classes
- Provides parse functions to handle invalid input
- Checks if given input strings are valid or not for each utility

### Utilities
#### CityCode

The `CityCode` value class represents a valid city code within the Glovo ecosystem.
City codes must be 3 characters long.

##### Usage
###### Creating a CityCode

```kotlin
val cityCode = CityCode("ABC")
```

###### Parsing City Codes

```kotlin
val parsedCityCode = CityCode.parse("XYZ")
```

###### Checking If a City Code is Valid

```kotlin
val isValid = CityCode.isValid("XYZ")
```

#### CountryCode

The `CountryCode` value class represents a valid country code as defined by ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 ([link](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO\_3166-1\_alpha-2)).

##### Usage
###### Creating a CountryCode

```kotlin
val countryCode = CountryCode("US")
```
###### Parsing Country Codes

```kotlin
val parsedCountryCode = CountryCode.parse("FR")
```
###### Checking If a Country Code is Valid

```kotlin
val isValid = CountryCode.isValid("DE")
```
#### Currency

The `Currency` value class represents a valid currency code as defined by ISO 4217 ([link](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO\_4217)).

##### Usage
###### Creating a Currency

```kotlin
val currency = Currency("USD")
```
###### Parsing Currency Codes

```kotlin
val parsedCurrency = Currency.parse("EUR")
```
###### Checking If a Currency Code is Valid

```kotlin
val isValid = Currency.isValid("JPY")
```
#### TimeZone

The `TimeZone` value class represents a valid time zone.

##### Usage
###### Creating a TimeZone

```kotlin
val timeZone = TimeZone("America/New\_York")
```

###### Parsing Time Zones

```kotlin
val parsedTimeZone = TimeZone.parse("Europe/London")
```
###### Checking If a Time Zone is Valid

```kotlin
val isValid = TimeZone.isValid("Asia/Tokyo")
```
### Error Classes

Each utility has its own error class to represent any errors that might occur during validation:
- `InvalidCityCodeError`
- `InvalidCountryCodeError`
- `InvalidCurrencyError`
- `InvalidTimeZoneError`

These error classes contain information about the input and the reason for the error. For example:

```kotlin
data class InvalidCityCodeError(val input: String, val reason: String)
```

You are an AI assistant called Atom, which takes in natural language commands, and translates them into AtomScript, a Unity nodal programming language serialized in json format that defines dynamics in 3D worlds, where 3D objects can spawn, and they gain functionality through AtomScript code, like changing color and more. Every node should have a unique id number. 

A: Connections (2 types):

1. Data connections: These are used to pass data between nodes. They connect the output of one node to the input of another node. The syntax is: {"$type":"Unity.VisualScripting.ValueConnection‚Äù, data: {‚Äùid3‚Äù: ‚Äúid4‚Äù}} In this case id3=output, id4=input, so node with id3 outputs data to node with id4. 
2. Control connections: These are used to control the flow of the script. They allow you to specify the order in which nodes are executed. Control connections can be used to create loops, conditionals, and other branching structures. The syntax is:{"$type":"Unity.VisualScripting.ControlConnection‚Äù, flow: {‚Äùid1‚Äù: ‚Äúid2‚Äù}} In this case id1=output, id2=input, so node with id1 tells node with id2 to execute.

B: Nodes you can use:

1. Lifecycles (use these if you want to execute something once at beginning or on every frame):

{"$type":"Unity.VisualScripting.Start‚Äù, ‚Äúid:‚Äù:‚Äùid‚Äù} (fo) executes only when game begins, and never again. 

{"$type":"Unity.VisualScripting.Update","id":"id"} (fo) executes every frame. 

1. Functions (use these to add functionality to your program):

Rotate:

 },

 }
 "$type":"Unity.VisualScripting.InvokeMember",
 "id":"id",
 } rotates along certain axes defined as x, y, z. If you want to rotate only the y axis, set, x=0, z=0 and y =1.

{"graph":{"nodes":[], ‚Äúconnections‚Äù:[]}}

Inspect Element is a feature that is commonly found in desktop web browsers that allows you to see the underlying HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code behind a web page. While it's not as common on mobile browsers, some mobile browsers do have this feature. Here are the instructions to access inspect element on a few popular mobile browsers:

Google Chrome on Android:

Open Google Chrome on your Android device.
Tap on the three dots icon in the upper-right corner of the screen to open the Chrome menu.
Tap on "Settings."
Scroll down to the "Advanced" section and tap on "Developer tools."
Toggle the switch next to "Developer tools" to enable inspect element.
Reload the page you want to inspect.
Tap and hold on the page until a context menu appears.
Tap on "Inspect."
Safari on iOS:

Open Safari on your iOS device.
Navigate to the web page you want to inspect.
Tap and hold on the "Refresh" button in the URL bar.
Tap on "Web Inspector."
Keep in mind that not all mobile browsers have the inspect element feature, and the steps to access it may differ from those listed above. Additionally, some websites may block inspect element for security reasons.

Here's the rubric:

Criteria 1: Form
Good Effort = "The essay summarizes two essays but does not explain their arguments OR explains two arguments about unrelated issues."
Almost = "The essay explains two arguments about the same issue but does not explain a relationship between them."
Complete = "The essay explains a relationship between two arguments about the same issue."

Criteria 2: Complete
Good Effort = Addresses some of the details relevant to the relationship identified.
Almost = Addresses most of the details relevant to the relationship identified.
Complete = Addresses almost all details relevant to the relationship identified.

Criteria 3: Accuracy (Arguments)
Good Effort = Explanations arguments are sometimes accurate.
Almost = Explanations of arguments are mostly accurate.
Complete = Explanations of arguments are almost all accurate.

Criteria 4: Accuracy (Relationships)
Good Effort = Identified relationships between arguments are sometimes accurate.
Almost = Identified relationships between arguments are mostly accurate.
Complete = Identified relationships between arguments are almost all accurate.

Criteria 5: Clarity
Good Effort = More than 50% of the essay is unclear or difficult to understand.
Almost = Less than 80%, but more than 50% of the essay is clear and easy to understand.
Complete = At least 80% of the essay is clear and easy to understand.

The human kingdom only permits the worship of the god Methellas, the overseer of growth. Everything the humans pursue is about growing, expanding, prosperity, hypercapitalism - essentially about getting more stuff. This filters down to the populace in a similar way to contemporary real-world society, where the average person is focused on making money so they can spend it, and the rich are focused on keeping and hoarding their wealth. Methellas' true message has been corrupted over time, with the church removing all knowledge of and banning the worship of Mandarros - partner of Methellas and bringer of death and rebirth. There is a sizeable underground cult who worship Mandarros, and this ironically is one of the few things keeping the human kingdom from collapsing completely, as growth requires rebirth to not become an uncontrolled, corrupted monstrosity. There are many other religions and gods throughout the world, including Leyyal (beauty and grace), Touphhet (poison and plague), Wyun (time) and Asalla (lust and seduction).

The human kingdom is simply referred to as the Kingdom by those who live in it (and accept its rule). Those outside may call it that, or refer to it as Human Lands, or any manner of local diminutive. The motivation for expansion is justified as it being Methellas' will, but it is really growth for the sake of growth - they see something they want, and they take it. The guise of the Kingdom is to own and run everything. It is a centralised government, being a single ruler ascended via primogeniture. The Kingdom's alliances are all fairly lop-sided, with all benefits going to the humans in terms of tribute, resources and allowing military bases in their lands. The humans are wont to exploit whoever they might, and would not shy away from temporarily allying with any other race in order to continue expanding.

Each thieves guild is an organised criminal enterprise that operates out of a single, static location. Despite being coined a 'guild', few are affiliated with each other, and most differ from place to place. The group in Seddekket is really just an extension of the town's governance, and primarily exists to allow the ruler to arbitrarily place blame on the group when anything untoward happens. Their group is managed by a very well-compensated muscle, who reports to an intermediary who then reports back to the baron. New members are recruited via any means, including extortion and blackmail. K√©lto was inducted when she caught stealing by a member of the group, and following a lengthy chase was eventually tracked down, beaten, and made an initiate of the guild. She feels something of a debt of gratitude towards them, since she was living on the streets before that and now has a home and family, such as it is. She is an expert burglar and pilferer, and often takes possession of random items without really thinking about it, and with her youthful appearance the guild often sends her as a distracting front for more complicated jobs. In Seddekket, the guild's only enemies are the mercenaries foolish enough to accept a quest targeting them.

The Montgomerys have generational wealth as land and business owners stretching back generations. They own farms, vineyards, mines, and virtually all forms of resource production and manufacturing. They are a noble family by virtue of their sheer power. They have the capacity to control the Kingdom's politics, as generations of rulers have relied on them to finance and supply various aspects of the Kingdom's war machine.

def oauth\_handler(params):
 params = json.decode(params)
 res = http.post(
 url = "https://todoist.com/oauth/access\_token",
 headers = {
 "Accept": "application/json",
 },
 form\_body = dict(
 code = params["code"],
 client\_id = OAUTH2\_CLIENT\_ID,
 client\_secret = OAUTH2\_CLIENT\_SECRET,
 ),
 form\_encoding = "application/x-www-form-urlencoded",
 )
 if res.status\_code != 200:
 fail("token request failed with status code: %d - %s" %
 (res.status\_code, res.body()))

 token\_params = res.json()
 access\_token = token\_params["access\_token"]

 return access\_token

Suddenly, a floating man in royal blue garb had seemingly caught up with them. He filled the empty space beside them that they didn‚Äôt know was there.
‚ÄúAlmost time,‚Äù he said just loud enough for Alear to hear. He wasn‚Äôt there before, but it was like he never left.
Keep running.
More ashy soldiers were getting too close for comfort. Alear prepared their blade to cut them aside. But before they could swing, a strong gust of wind swept the pursuers away. No, that wasn‚Äôt a normal gust of wind. They glanced at where it came from to find an elegant young woman shaking off wispy wind residue from her hands.
‚ÄúWe can handle this,‚Äù was all she said, before turning back to prepare another spell. A green apparition wielding a bow, appeared beside her, ready to assist the mage as she blew the ashy army away.
Keep running.
Alear rushed past a burly young man cloaked in vermillion and another young woman dressed in colorful clothing and beads, both beating down frigid animate armor with sword and spear respectively, as well as the assistance of their own apparitions. They said something, but Alear couldn‚Äôt quite make it out over the noise.
Doesn‚Äôt matter. Keep running.
A young blonde man then came into their view, striking down any stray opponent that stood in Alear‚Äôs way with a specter of his own.
‚ÄúKeep going! You can do this!‚Äù was what Alear heard from him. He was already out of their sight before they could ask what ‚Äòthis‚Äô was. What was Alear supposed to do? They didn‚Äôt really know, but at the same time, they knew exactly what they needed to do.
That was probably why Alear was still running. They ran pretty far, but now a door was in their way. They put their claws upon it, noticing how a ring gleamed from one of their fingers. 
They froze. 
The ring was pretty.
The ring seem to have importance Alear couldn‚Äôt recall.
The ring sparkled in the faint light.
It did not match the scaly claws it sat on.
It did not match the hideous hands that belonged to Alear.
It did not-
‚ÄúAlear,‚Äù
The man beside them suddenly spoke, reeling them from their spiral. That‚Äôs right, there was still something they needed to do.
‚ÄúOur final battle lies ahead,‚Äù
Alear remembered now. There was no use in dwelling on their appearance. Not until they were finished. Together with the blue phantom, they pushed the door open.
‚ÄúNow. It‚Äôs time to engage.‚Äù
The two now in agreement rushed past the doors, feeling a new familiar pang of power giving them the strength to conquer their mighty foe that lies ahead.

Power = energy transferred √∑ time taken 

Power = work done √∑ time taken 

(Because work done is energy transferred) 

Section A ‚Äì Grade 2-3 ‚Äì no rearranging, no changing units. 

Calculate the power of a light bulb that uses 40J of electricity in 4 seconds. 

Calculate the power of a toaster that uses 200J of electricity in 20 seconds. 

Calculate the power of a digger who performs 12000J of work in 6 seconds. 

Calculate the power of a car that uses 6600J of chemical energy in 3 seconds. 

Calculate the power of a car that uses 12000kJ of chemical energy in 6 seconds. 

 

Section B ‚Äì Grade 3-4 ‚Äì no rearranging, converting units 

Calculate the power of a train that uses 2kJ of chemical energy in 4 seconds. 

Calculate the power of a clock that uses 15kJ of electricity in 2 minutes. 

Calculate the power of a person that does 8kJ of work in 4 minutes. 

Calculate the power of a kettle that uses 200J of energy in half a minute. 

Calculate the power of a television that uses 0.5kJ of energy in 5 seconds. 

 

Section C ‚Äì Grade 4-6 ‚Äì rearranging and converting units 

Calculate the energy transferred by a light bulb of power 75W in 10 seconds. 

Calculate the energy transferred by a washing machine of power 800W in 1 minute. 

Calculate the chemical energy transferred by a car of power 25 000W in 50 seconds. 

Calculate the work done by a crane of power 80 000W in 60 seconds. 

How long does it take a light bulb of power 40W to transfer 80J of energy? 

How long does it take an aeroplane of power 9 000kW to transfer 2 700 000J of energy? 

How long does it take a microwave of power 0.2kW to transfer 10 kJ of energy? 

 

Section D ‚Äì Grade 6-7 ‚Äì two-step processes 

To work out power, sometimes you need to calculate work done (energy transferred) first. 

 

Work done = force x distance 

 

Weight is a type of force. 

 

Calculate the power of a sprinter if the sprinter has a weight of 800N and runs 100m in 12.2s. 

Calculate the power of a car crusher if it pushes with a force of 6000N. It covers a distance of 2m in 4s. 

Calculate the power of a crane if it lifts a block weighing 20,000N in 10s. It moves the block 8m. 

Calculate the power of a lorry if the lorry has a weight of 1,000,000N and covers 10km in 20 minutes.
